CHAPTER I. [OUR]275-our SOCIETY IN the first place , [Cranford]1-cranford is in possession of [the Amazons]276-the amazons ; [all the holders of [houses above a certain rent]278-houses above a certain rent]277-all the holders of houses above a certain rent are [women]279-women . If [a married couple]280-a married couple come to settle in [the town]281-the town , somehow [the gentleman]282-the gentleman disappears ; [he]282-the gentleman is either fairly frightened to death by being [the only man in the [Cranford]1-cranford evening parties]283-the only man in the cranford evening parties , or [he]282-the gentleman is accounted for by being with [[his]282-the gentleman regiment]284-his regiment , [[his]282-the gentleman ship]285-his ship , or closely engaged in business all the week in [the great neighbouring commercial town of [Drumble]2-drumble]286-the great neighbouring commercial town of drumble , distant only twenty miles on [a railroad]287-a railroad . In short , whatever does become of [the gentlemen]288-the gentlemen , [they]288-the gentlemen are not at [Cranford]1-cranford . What could [they]288-the gentlemen do if [they]288-the gentlemen were [there]289-there ? [The surgeon]290-the surgeon has [his]290-the surgeon round of thirty miles , and sleeps at [Cranford]1-cranford ; but [every man]291-every man can not be [a surgeon]292-a surgeon . For keeping [the trim gardens]293-the trim gardens full of choice flowers without a weed to speck them ; for frightening away [little boys who look wistfully at the said flowers through the railings]294-little boys who look wistfully at the said flowers through the railings ; for rushing out at the geese that occasionally venture in to [the gardens]295-the gardens if the gates are left open ; for deciding all questions of literature and politics without troubling [themselves]288-the gentlemen with unnecessary reasons or arguments ; for obtaining clear and correct knowledge of [everybody]296-everybody ’s affairs in [the parish]297-the parish ; for keeping [[their]288-the gentlemen neat maid - servants]298-their neat maid - servants in admirable order ; for kindness ( somewhat dictatorial ) to [the poor]299-the poor , and real tender good offices to each other whenever [they]288-the gentlemen are in distress , [the ladies of [Cranford]1-cranford]300-the ladies of cranford are quite sufficient . “ [A man]2058-a man , ”[300-the ladies of cranford] as one of [them]300-the ladies of cranford observed to [me]0-i once , “ is _ so _ in the way in [the house]2059-the house ! ”[300-the ladies of cranford] Although [the ladies of [Cranford]1-cranford]300-the ladies of cranford know all [each other]302-each other ’s proceedings , [they]300-the ladies of cranford are exceedingly indifferent to [each other]302-each other ’s opinions . Indeed , as [each]304-each has [her]304-each own individuality , not to say eccentricity , pretty strongly developed , nothing is so easy as verbal retaliation ; but , somehow , good - will reigns among [them]300-the ladies of cranford to a considerable degree . [The Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies have only an occasional little quarrel , spirited out in a few peppery words and angry jerks of the head ; just enough to prevent the even tenor of [their]305-the cranford ladies lives from becoming too flat . [Their]305-the cranford ladies dress is very independent of fashion ; as [they]305-the cranford ladies observe , “ What does it signify how [we]305-the cranford ladies dress here at [Cranford]1-cranford , where [everybody]296-everybody knows [us]305-the cranford ladies ? ”[305-the cranford ladies] And if [they]305-the cranford ladies go from [home]306-home , [their]305-the cranford ladies reason is equally cogent , “ What does it signify how [we]305-the cranford ladies dress here , where [nobody]2061-nobody knows [us]305-the cranford ladies ? ”[305-the cranford ladies] The materials of [their]305-the cranford ladies clothes are , in general , good and plain , and most of [them]305-the cranford ladies are nearly as scrupulous as [Miss Tyler]74-miss tyler , of cleanly memory ; but [I]0-i will answer for it , the last gigot , the last tight and scanty petticoat in wear in [England]3-england , was seen in [Cranford]1-cranford — and seen without a smile . [ Picture : A magnificent family red silk umbrella ] [I]0-i can testify to a magnificent family red silk umbrella , under which [a gentle little spinster , left alone of many brothers]307-a gentle little spinster , left alone of many brothers and [sisters]308-sisters , used to patter to [church]309-church on rainy days . Have [you]310-you any red silk umbrellas in [London]4-london ? [We]311-our had a tradition of the first that had ever been seen in [Cranford]1-cranford ; and [the little boys]312-the little boys mobbed [it]313-it , and called it “ a stick in petticoats . ”[312-the little boys] It might have been the very red silk one [I]0-i have described , held by [a strong father]314-a strong father over [a troop of [little ones]316-little ones]315-a troop of little ones ; [the poor little lady]317-the poor little lady — [the survivor of all]318-the survivor of all — could scarcely carry it . Then there were rules and regulations for visiting and calls ; and they were announced to [any young people who might be staying in [the town]281-the town , with all the solemnity with which the old Manx laws were read once a year on [the Tinwald Mount]5-the tinwald mount]319-any young people who might be staying in the town , with all the solemnity with which the old manx laws were read once a year on the tinwald mount . “ [[Our]311-our friends]2062-our friends have sent to inquire how [you]310-you are after [your]310-you journey to - night , [[my]321-a gentleman dear]2063-my dear ”[321-a gentleman] ( fifteen miles in [a gentleman]321-a gentleman ’s carriage ) ; “ [they]322-they will give [you]310-you some rest to - morrow , but the next day , [I]321-a gentleman have no doubt , [they]322-they will call ; so be at liberty after twelve — from twelve to three are [our]311-our calling hours . ”[321-a gentleman] Then , after [they]322-they had called — “ It is the third day ; [I]321-a gentleman dare say [[your]310-you mamma]2064-your mamma has told [you]310-you , [[my]321-a gentleman dear]2063-my dear , never to let more than three days elapse between receiving a call and returning it ; and also , that [you]310-you are never to stay longer than a quarter of an hour . ”[321-a gentleman] “ But am [I]321-a gentleman to look at [my]321-a gentleman watch ? How am [I]321-a gentleman to find out when a quarter of an hour has passed ? ”[321-a gentleman] “ [You]310-you must keep thinking about the time , [[my]321-a gentleman dear]2063-my dear , and not allow [yourself]310-you to forget it in conversation . ”[321-a gentleman] As [everybody]296-everybody had this rule in [their]296-everybody minds , whether [they]296-everybody received or paid a call , of course no absorbing subject was ever spoken about . [We]324-we kept [ourselves]324-we to short sentences of small talk , and were punctual to [our]324-we time . [I]0-i imagine that [a few of [the gentlefolks of]326-the gentlefolks of [Cranford]1-cranford]325-a few of the gentlefolks of cranford were poor , and had some difficulty in making both ends meet ; but [they]325-a few of the gentlefolks of cranford were like [the Spartans]75-the spartans , and concealed [their]325-a few of the gentlefolks of cranford smart under a smiling face . [We]324-we none of [us]324-we spoke of money , because [that subject]327-that subject savoured of commerce and trade , and though some might be poor , [we]324-we were all aristocratic . [The Cranfordians]76-the cranfordians had that kindly _ esprit de corps _ which made [them]76-the cranfordians overlook all deficiencies in success when some among [them]76-the cranfordians tried to conceal [their]76-the cranfordians poverty . When [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester , for instance , gave a party in [[her]77-mrs forrester baby - house of [a dwelling]329-a dwelling]328-her baby - house of a dwelling , and [the little maiden]330-the little maiden disturbed [the ladies on the sofa]331-the ladies on the sofa by a request that [she]330-the little maiden might get the tea - tray out from underneath , [everyone]332-everyone took this novel proceeding as the most natural thing in [the world]333-the world , and talked on about household forms and ceremonies as if [we]324-we all believed that [[our]324-we hostess]334-our hostess had [a regular [servants]336-servants ’ hall]335-a regular servants ’ hall , second table , with [housekeeper]337-housekeeper and [steward]338-steward , instead of [the one little charity - school maiden , whose short ruddy arms could never have been strong enough to carry the tray [upstairs]340-upstairs , if [she]330-the little maiden had not been assisted in private by [[her]330-the little maiden mistress]341-her mistress , who now sat in state , pretending not to know what cakes were sent up , though [she]330-the little maiden knew , and [we]324-we knew , and [she]330-the little maiden knew that [we]324-we knew , and [we]324-we knew that [she]330-the little maiden knew that [we]324-we knew , [she]330-the little maiden had been busy all the morning making tea - bread and sponge - cakes]339-the one little charity - school maiden , whose short ruddy arms could never have been strong enough to carry the tray upstairs , if she had not been assisted in private by her mistress , who now sat in state , pretending not to know what cakes were sent up , though she knew , and we knew , and she knew that we knew , and we knew that she knew that we knew , she had been busy all the morning making tea - bread and sponge - cakes . There were one or two consequences arising from this general but unacknowledged poverty , and this very much acknowledged gentility , which were not amiss , and which might be introduced into [many circles of society]342-many circles of society to [their]342-many circles of society great improvement . For instance , [the inhabitants of [Cranford]1-cranford]343-the inhabitants of cranford kept early hours , and clattered [home]306-home in [their]343-the inhabitants of cranford pattens , under the guidance of [a lantern - bearer]345-a lantern - bearer , about nine o’clock at night ; and [the whole town]346-the whole town was abed and asleep by half - past ten . Moreover , it was considered “ vulgar ”[78-mrs jamieson] ( a tremendous word in [Cranford]1-cranford ) to give anything expensive , in the way of eatable or drinkable , at the evening entertainments . Wafer bread - and - butter and sponge - biscuits were all that [the Honourable Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson gave ; and [she]78-mrs jamieson was sister - in - law to [the late Earl of Glenmire]79-the late earl of glenmire , although [she]78-mrs jamieson did practise such “ elegant economy . ”[78-mrs jamieson] “ Elegant economy ! ”[78-mrs jamieson] How naturally one falls back into the phraseology of [Cranford]1-cranford ! There , economy was always “ elegant , ”[78-mrs jamieson] and money - spending always “ vulgar and ostentatious ”[78-mrs jamieson] ; a sort of sour - grapeism which made [us]324-we very peaceful and satisfied . [I]0-i never shall forget the dismay felt when [a certain [Captain Brown]80-captain brown]347-a certain captain brown came to live at [Cranford]1-cranford , and openly spoke about [his]347-a certain captain brown being poor — not in a whisper to [an intimate friend]348-an intimate friend , the doors and windows being previously closed , but in [the public street]349-the public street ! in a loud military voice ! alleging [his]347-a certain captain brown poverty as a reason for not taking [a particular house]350-a particular house . [The ladies of [Cranford]1-cranford]300-the ladies of cranford were already rather moaning over the invasion of [[their]300-the ladies of cranford territories]352-their territories by [a man]2058-a man and [a gentleman]321-a gentleman . [He]347-a certain captain brown was [a half - pay captain]355-a half - pay captain , and had obtained some situation on [a neighbouring railroad]356-a neighbouring railroad , which had been vehemently petitioned against by [the little town]357-the little town ; and if , in addition to [his]347-a certain captain brown masculine gender , and [his]347-a certain captain brown connection with [the obnoxious railroad]358-the obnoxious railroad , [he]347-a certain captain brown was so brazen as to talk of being poor — why , then , indeed , [he]347-a certain captain brown must be sent to [Coventry]6-coventry . Death was as true and as common as poverty ; yet [people]359-people never spoke about that , loud out in [the streets]360-the streets . It was a word not to be mentioned to ears polite . [We]361-we had tacitly agreed to ignore that [any with whom [we]361-we associated on terms of visiting equality]362-any with whom we associated on terms of visiting equality could ever be prevented by poverty from doing anything that [they]362-any with whom we associated on terms of visiting equality wished . If [we]361-we walked to or from a party , it was because the night was _ so _ fine , or the air _ so _ refreshing , not because sedan - chairs were expensive . If [we]361-we wore prints , instead of summer silks , it was because [we]361-we preferred a washing material ; and so on , till [we]361-we blinded [ourselves]361-we to the vulgar fact that [we]361-we were , all of [us]361-we , [people of very moderate means]363-people of very moderate means . Of course , then , [we]361-we did not know what to make of [a man who could speak of poverty as if it was not a disgrace]364-a man who could speak of poverty as if it was not a disgrace . Yet , somehow , [Captain Brown]80-captain brown made [himself]80-captain brown respected in [Cranford]1-cranford , and was called upon , in spite of all resolutions to the contrary . [I]0-i was surprised to hear [his]80-captain brown opinions quoted as authority at a visit which [I]0-i paid to [Cranford]1-cranford about a year after [he]80-captain brown had settled in [the town]281-the town . [[My]0-i own friends]366-my own friends had been among the bitterest opponents of any proposal to visit [the Captain]367-the captain and [[his]367-the captain daughters]368-his daughters , only twelve months before ; and now [he]80-captain brown was even admitted in the tabooed hours before twelve . True , it was to discover the cause of a smoking chimney , before the fire was lighted ; but still [Captain Brown]80-captain brown walked [upstairs]340-upstairs , nothing daunted , spoke in a voice too large for [the room]370-the room , and joked quite in the way of [a tame man]371-a tame man about [the house]2059-the house . [He]80-captain brown had been blind to all the small slights , and omissions of trivial ceremonies , with which [he]80-captain brown had been received . [He]80-captain brown had been friendly , though [the Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies had been cool ; [he]80-captain brown had answered small sarcastic compliments in good faith ; and with [his]80-captain brown manly frankness had overpowered all the shrinking which met [him]80-captain brown as [a man who was not ashamed to be poor]374-a man who was not ashamed to be poor . And , at last , [his]80-captain brown excellent masculine common sense , and [his]80-captain brown facility in devising expedients to overcome domestic dilemmas , had gained [him]80-captain brown an extraordinary place as authority among [the Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies . [He]80-captain brown [himself]80-captain brown went on in [his]80-captain brown course , as unaware of [his]80-captain brown popularity as [he]80-captain brown had been of [the reverse]376-the reverse ; and [I]0-i am sure [he]80-captain brown was startled one day when [he]80-captain brown found [his]80-captain brown advice so highly esteemed as to make some counsel which [he]80-captain brown had given in jest to be taken in sober , serious earnest . It was on this subject : [An old lady]377-an old lady had an Alderney cow , which [she]377-an old lady looked upon as [a daughter]378-a daughter . [You]379-you could not pay the short quarter of an hour call without being told of the wonderful milk or wonderful intelligence of this animal . [The whole town]346-the whole town knew and kindly regarded [Miss Betsy Barker]81-miss barker ’s [Alderney]7-alderney ; therefore great was the sympathy and regret when , in an unguarded moment , the poor cow tumbled into a lime - pit . [She]81-miss barker moaned so loudly that [she]81-miss barker was soon heard and rescued ; but meanwhile the poor beast had lost most of [her]81-miss barker hair , and came out looking naked , cold , and miserable , in a bare skin . [Everybody]82-everybody pitied the animal , though a few could not restrain [their]381-their smiles at [her]81-miss barker droll appearance . [Miss Betsy Barker]81-miss barker absolutely cried with sorrow and dismay ; and it was said [she]81-miss barker thought of trying a bath of oil . This remedy , perhaps , was recommended by [some one of the number whose advice [she]81-miss barker asked]382-some one of the number whose advice she asked ; but the proposal , if ever it was made , was knocked on the head by [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ’s decided “ Get [her]81-miss barker a flannel waistcoat and flannel drawers , [ma’am]2067-ma’am , if [you]2067-ma’am wish to keep [her]81-miss barker alive . But [my]80-captain brown advice is , kill [the poor creature]2068-the poor creature at once . ”[80-captain brown] [Miss Betsy Barker]81-miss barker dried [her]81-miss barker eyes , and thanked [the Captain]367-the captain heartily ; [she]81-miss barker set to work , and by - and - by all [the town]281-the town turned out to see [the Alderney]7-alderney meekly going to [[her]7-alderney pasture]385-her pasture , clad in dark grey flannel . [I]0-i have watched [her]7-alderney [myself]0-i many a time . Do [you]386-you ever see cows dressed in grey flannel in [London]4-london ? [ Picture : [Meekly]84-meekly going to [[her]7-alderney pasture]385-her pasture ] [Captain Brown]80-captain brown had taken [a small house on [the outskirts of [the town]281-the town]389-the outskirts of the town , where [he]80-captain brown lived with [[his]80-captain brown two daughters]391-his two daughters]388-a small house on the outskirts of the town , where he lived with his two daughters . [He]80-captain brown must have been upwards of sixty at the time of the first visit [I]0-i paid to [Cranford]1-cranford after [I]0-i had left [it]388-a small house on the outskirts of the town , where he lived with his two daughters as [a residence]392-a residence . But [he]80-captain brown had a wiry , well - trained , elastic figure , a stiff military throw - back of [his]80-captain brown head , and a springing step , which made [him]80-captain brown appear much younger than [he]80-captain brown was . [[His]80-captain brown eldest daughter]393-his eldest daughter looked almost as old as [himself]80-captain brown , and betrayed the fact that [his]80-captain brown real was more than [his]80-captain brown apparent age . [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie must have been forty ; [she]85-miss jessie had a sickly , pained , careworn expression on [her]85-miss jessie face , and looked as if the gaiety of youth had long faded out of sight . Even when young [she]85-miss jessie must have been plain and hard - featured . [Miss Jessie Brown]85-miss jessie was ten years younger than [[her]85-miss jessie sister]394-her sister , and twenty shades prettier . [Her]85-miss jessie face was round and dimpled . [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns once said , in a passion against [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ( the cause of which [I]0-i will tell [you]395-you presently ) , “ that [she]85-miss jessie thought it was time for [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie to leave off [her]85-miss jessie dimples , and not always to be trying to look like [a child]2069-a child . ”[86-miss jenkyns] It was true there was something childlike in [her]85-miss jessie face ; and there will be , [I]0-i think , till [she]85-miss jessie dies , though [she]85-miss jessie should live to a hundred . [Her]85-miss jessie eyes were large blue wondering eyes , looking straight at [you]395-you ; [her]85-miss jessie nose was unformed and snub , and [her]85-miss jessie lips were red and dewy ; [she]85-miss jessie wore [her]85-miss jessie hair , too , in little rows of curls , which heightened this appearance . [I]0-i do not know whether [she]85-miss jessie was pretty or not ; but [I]0-i liked [her]85-miss jessie face , and so did [everybody]296-everybody , and [I]0-i do not think [she]85-miss jessie could help [her]85-miss jessie dimples . [She]85-miss jessie had something of [[her]85-miss jessie father]397-her father ’s jauntiness of gait and manner ; and [any female observer]398-any female observer might detect a slight difference in the attire of [the two sisters]399-the two sisters — that of [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie being about two pounds per annum more expensive than [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie ’s . Two pounds was a large sum in [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ’s annual disbursements . Such was the impression made upon [me]0-i by [the Brown family]400-the brown family when [I]0-i first saw [them]400-the brown family all together in [Cranford Church]8-cranford church . The Captain [I]0-i had met before — on the occasion of the smoky chimney , which [he]80-captain brown had cured by some simple alteration in the flue . In [church]309-church , [he]80-captain brown held [his]80-captain brown double eye - glass to [his]80-captain brown eyes during the Morning Hymn , and then lifted up [his]80-captain brown head erect and sang out loud and joyfully . [He]80-captain brown made the responses louder than [the clerk]402-the clerk — [an old man with a piping feeble voice]403-an old man with a piping feeble voice , who , [I]0-i think , felt aggrieved at [the Captain]367-the captain ’s sonorous bass , and quivered higher and higher in consequence . On coming out of [church]309-church , [the brisk Captain]406-the brisk captain paid the most gallant attention to [[his]80-captain brown two daughters]391-his two daughters . [He]80-captain brown nodded and smiled to [[his]80-captain brown acquaintances]408-his acquaintances ; but [he]80-captain brown shook hands with none until [he]80-captain brown had helped [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie to unfurl [her]85-miss jessie umbrella , had relieved [her]85-miss jessie of [her]85-miss jessie prayer - book , and had waited patiently till [she]85-miss jessie , with trembling nervous hands , had taken up [her]85-miss jessie gown to walk through [the wet roads]409-the wet roads . [I]0-i wonder what [the Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies did with [Captain Brown]80-captain brown at [their]305-the cranford ladies parties . [We]411-we had often rejoiced , in former days , that there was [no gentleman to be attended to , and to find conversation for , at the card - parties]412-no gentleman to be attended to , and to find conversation for , at the card - parties . [We]411-we had congratulated [ourselves]411-we upon the snugness of the evenings ; and , in [our]411-we love for gentility , and distaste of mankind , [we]411-we had almost persuaded [ourselves]411-we that to be [a man]2058-a man was to be “ vulgar ”[2058-a man] ; so that when [I]0-i found [[my]0-i friend]414-my friend and [hostess]415-hostess , [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns , was going to have a party in [my]0-i honour , and that [Captain]80-captain brown and [the Miss Browns]87-the browns were invited , [I]0-i wondered much what would be the course of the evening . Card - tables , with green baize tops , were set out by daylight , just as usual ; it was the third week in November , so the evenings closed in about four . Candles , and clean packs of cards , were arranged on each table . The fire was made up ; [the neat maid - servant]416-the neat maid - servant had received [her]416-the neat maid - servant last directions ; and there [we]411-we stood , dressed in [our]411-we best , each with a candle - lighter in [our]411-we hands , ready to dart at the candles as soon as the first knock came . Parties in [Cranford]1-cranford were solemn festivities , making [the ladies]417-the ladies feel gravely elated as [they]417-the ladies sat together in [their]417-the ladies best dresses . As soon as three had arrived , [we]411-we sat down to “ Preference , ”[0-i] [I]0-i being [the unlucky fourth]418-the unlucky fourth . [The next four comers]419-the next four comers were put down immediately to another table ; and presently the tea - trays , which [I]0-i had seen set out in [the store - room]420-the store - room as [I]0-i passed in the morning , were placed each on the middle of a card - table . The china was delicate egg - shell ; the old - fashioned silver glittered with polishing ; but the eatables were of the slightest description . While the trays were yet on the tables , [Captain]80-captain brown and [the Miss Browns]87-the browns came in ; and [I]0-i could see that , somehow or other , [the Captain]367-the captain was a favourite with [all the ladies present]422-all the ladies present . Ruffled brows were smoothed , sharp voices lowered at [his]367-the captain approach . [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie looked ill , and depressed almost to gloom . [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie smiled as usual , and seemed nearly as popular as [[her]85-miss jessie father]397-her father . [He]397-her father immediately and quietly assumed [the man]424-the man ’s place in [the room]370-the room ; attended to [every one]426-every one ’s wants , lessened [the pretty maid - servant]427-the pretty maid - servant ’s labour by waiting on empty cups and [bread - and - butterless ladies]428-bread - and - butterless ladies ; and yet did it all in so easy and dignified a manner , and so much as if it were a matter of course for [the strong]429-the strong to attend to [the weak]430-the weak , that [he]397-her father was [a true man]431-a true man throughout . [He]397-her father played for threepenny points with as grave an interest as if [they]432-they had been pounds ; and yet , in all [his]397-her father attention to [strangers]433-strangers , [he]397-her father had an eye on [[his]397-her father suffering daughter]434-his suffering daughter — for suffering [I]0-i was sure [she]434-his suffering daughter was , though to many eyes [she]434-his suffering daughter might only appear to be irritable . [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie could not play cards : but [she]85-miss jessie talked to [the sitters - out]435-the sitters - out , who , before [her]85-miss jessie coming , had been rather inclined to be cross . [She]85-miss jessie sang , too , to an old cracked piano , which [I]0-i think had been a spinet in [its]436-its youth . [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie sang , “ Jock of [Hazeldean]88-hazeldean ”[85-miss jessie] a little out of tune ; but [we]437-we were none of [us]437-we musical , though [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns beat time , out of time , by way of appearing to be so . It was very good of [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns to do this ; for [I]0-i had seen that , a little before , [she]86-miss jenkyns had been a good deal annoyed by [Miss Jessie Brown]85-miss jessie ’s unguarded admission ( _ à propos _ of Shetland wool ) that [she]86-miss jenkyns had [an uncle]438-an uncle , [[[her]86-miss jenkyns mother]439-her mother ’s brother , who was [a shopkeeper in [Edinburgh]9-edinburgh]441-a shopkeeper in edinburgh]440-her mother ’s brother , who was a shopkeeper in edinburgh . [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns tried to drown this confession by a terrible cough — for [the Honourable Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson was sitting at a card - table nearest [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie , and what would [she]78-mrs jamieson say or think if [she]78-mrs jamieson found out [she]78-mrs jamieson was in [the same room]442-the same room with [[a shop - keeper]443-a shop - keeper ’s niece]444-a shop - keeper ’s niece ! But [Miss Jessie Brown]85-miss jessie ( who had no tact , as [we]445-our all agreed the next morning ) _ would _ repeat the information , and assure [Miss Pole]89-miss pole [she]89-miss pole could easily get [her]89-miss pole the identical Shetland wool required , “ through [[my]89-miss pole uncle]2070-my uncle , who has the best assortment of Shetland goods of any one in [Edinbro ’]10-edinbro ’ . ”[89-miss pole] It was to take the taste of this out of [our]445-our mouths , and the sound of this out of [our]445-our ears , that [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns proposed music ; so [I]0-i say again , it was very good of [her]86-miss jenkyns to beat time to the song . When the trays re - appeared with biscuits and wine , punctually at a quarter to nine , there was conversation , comparing of cards , and talking over tricks ; but by - and - by [Captain Brown]80-captain brown sported a bit of literature . “ Have [you]86-miss jenkyns seen any numbers of ‘ [The Pickwick Papers]90-the pickwick papers ’ ? ”[80-captain brown] said [he]80-captain brown . ( They were then publishing in parts . ) “ Capital thing ! ”[80-captain brown] Now [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns was [daughter of [a deceased rector of [Cranford]1-cranford]447-a deceased rector of cranford]446-daughter of a deceased rector of cranford ; and , on the strength of a number of manuscript sermons , and a pretty good library of divinity , considered [herself]86-miss jenkyns literary , and looked upon any conversation about books as a challenge to [her]86-miss jenkyns . So [she]86-miss jenkyns answered and said , “ Yes , [she]86-miss jenkyns had seen them ; indeed , [she]86-miss jenkyns might say [she]86-miss jenkyns had read them . ”[86-miss jenkyns] “ And what do [you]86-miss jenkyns think of them ? ”[80-captain brown] exclaimed [Captain Brown]80-captain brown . “ Are n’t they famously good ? ”[86-miss jenkyns] So urged [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns could not but speak . “ [I]86-miss jenkyns must say , [I]86-miss jenkyns do n’t think they are by any means equal to [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson . Still , perhaps , [the author]2071-the author is young . Let [him]2071-the author persevere , and who knows what [he]2071-the author may become if [he]2071-the author will take [the great Doctor]2072-the great doctor for [his]2071-the author model ? ”[86-miss jenkyns] This was evidently too much for [Captain Brown]80-captain brown to take placidly ; and [I]0-i saw the words on the tip of [his]80-captain brown tongue before [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns had finished [her]86-miss jenkyns sentence . “ It is quite a different sort of thing , [[my]80-captain brown dear madam]2073-my dear madam , ”[80-captain brown] [he]80-captain brown began . “ [I]86-miss jenkyns am quite aware of that , ”[86-miss jenkyns] returned [she]86-miss jenkyns . “ And [I]86-miss jenkyns make allowances , [Captain Brown]80-captain brown . ”[86-miss jenkyns] “ Just allow [me]80-captain brown to read [you]86-miss jenkyns a scene out of this month ’s number , ”[80-captain brown] pleaded [he]80-captain brown . “ [I]80-captain brown had it only this morning , and [I]80-captain brown do n’t think [the company]2074-the company can have read it yet . ”[80-captain brown] “ As [you]80-captain brown please , ”[86-miss jenkyns] said [she]86-miss jenkyns , settling [herself]86-miss jenkyns with an air of resignation . [He]80-captain brown read the account of the “ swarry ”[80-captain brown] which [Sam Weller]92-sam weller gave at [Bath]11-bath . [Some of [us]449-us]448-some of us laughed heartily . _ [I]0-i _ did not dare , because [I]0-i was staying in [the house]2059-the house . [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns sat in patient gravity . When it was ended , [she]86-miss jenkyns turned to [me]0-i , and said with mild dignity — “ Fetch [me]86-miss jenkyns ‘ [Rasselas]93-rasselas , ’ [[my]86-miss jenkyns dear]2063-my dear , out of [the book - room]2076-the book - room . ”[86-miss jenkyns] When [I]0-i had brought it to [her]86-miss jenkyns , [she]86-miss jenkyns turned to [Captain Brown]80-captain brown — “ Now allow _ [me]86-miss jenkyns _ to read [you]0-i a scene , and then [the present company]2077-the present company can judge between [[your]0-i favourite]2078-your favourite , [Mr Boz]94-mr boz , and [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson . ”[86-miss jenkyns] [She]86-miss jenkyns read one of the conversations between [Rasselas]93-rasselas and [Imlac]95-imlac , in a high - pitched , majestic voice : and when [she]86-miss jenkyns had ended , [she]86-miss jenkyns said , “ [I]86-miss jenkyns imagine [I]86-miss jenkyns am now justified in [my]86-miss jenkyns preference of [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson as [a writer of fiction]2079-a writer of fiction . ”[86-miss jenkyns] [The Captain]367-the captain screwed [his]367-the captain lips up , and drummed on the table , but [he]367-the captain did not speak . [She]86-miss jenkyns thought [she]86-miss jenkyns would give [him]367-the captain a finishing blow or two . [ Picture : Endeavouring to beguile [her]86-miss jenkyns into conversation ] “ [I]86-miss jenkyns consider it vulgar , and below the dignity of literature , to publish in numbers . ”[86-miss jenkyns] “ How was the _ Rambler _ published , [ma’am]2067-ma’am ? ”[80-captain brown] asked [Captain Brown]80-captain brown in a low voice , which [I]0-i think [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns could not have heard . “ [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson ’s style is a model for [young beginners]2081-young beginners . [[My]0-i father]2082-my father recommended it to [me]0-i when [I]0-i began to write letters — [I]0-i have formed [my]0-i own style upon it ; [I]0-i recommend it to [[your]367-the captain favourite]2078-your favourite . ”[0-i] “ [I]80-captain brown should be very sorry for [him]2078-your favourite to exchange [his]2078-your favourite style for any such pompous writing , ”[80-captain brown] said [Captain Brown]80-captain brown . [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns felt this as a personal affront , in a way of which [the Captain]367-the captain had not dreamed . Epistolary writing [she]86-miss jenkyns and [[her]86-miss jenkyns friends]453-her friends considered as [her]86-miss jenkyns _ forte _ . Many a copy of many a letter have [I]0-i seen written and corrected on the slate , before [she]86-miss jenkyns “ seized the half - hour just previous to post - time to assure ”[86-miss jenkyns] [[her]86-miss jenkyns friends]453-her friends of this or of that ; and [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson was , as [she]86-miss jenkyns said , [[her]86-miss jenkyns model]455-her model in these compositions . [She]86-miss jenkyns drew [herself]86-miss jenkyns up with dignity , and only replied to [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ’s last remark by saying , with marked emphasis on every syllable , “ [I]86-miss jenkyns prefer [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson to [Mr Boz]94-mr boz . ”[86-miss jenkyns] It is said — [I]0-i wo n’t vouch for the fact — that [Captain Brown]80-captain brown was heard to say , _ sotto voce _ , “ D — n [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson ! ”[80-captain brown] If [he]80-captain brown did , [he]80-captain brown was penitent afterwards , as [he]80-captain brown showed by going to stand near [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns ’ arm - chair , and endeavouring to beguile [her]86-miss jenkyns into conversation on some more pleasing subject . But [she]86-miss jenkyns was inexorable . The next day [she]86-miss jenkyns made the remark [I]0-i have mentioned about [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie ’s dimples . CHAPTER II . [THE CAPTAIN]367-the captain IT was impossible to live a month at [Cranford]1-cranford and not know the daily habits of [each resident]457-each resident ; and long before [my]0-i visit was ended [I]0-i knew much concerning [the whole Brown trio]458-the whole brown trio . There was nothing new to be discovered respecting [their]458-the whole brown trio poverty ; for [they]458-the whole brown trio had spoken simply and openly about that from the very first . [They]458-the whole brown trio made no mystery of the necessity for [their]458-the whole brown trio being economical . All that remained to be discovered was [the Captain]367-the captain ’s infinite kindness of heart , and the various modes in which , unconsciously to [himself]367-the captain , [he]367-the captain manifested it . Some little anecdotes were talked about for some time after they occurred . As [we]460-we did not read much , and as [all the ladies]461-all the ladies were pretty well suited with [servants]336-servants , there was a dearth of subjects for conversation . [We]460-we therefore discussed the circumstance of [the Captain]367-the captain taking [a poor old woman]464-a poor old woman ’s dinner out of [her]464-a poor old woman hands one very slippery Sunday . [He]367-the captain had met [her]464-a poor old woman returning from [the bakehouse]465-the bakehouse as [he]367-the captain came from [church]309-church , and noticed [her]464-a poor old woman precarious footing ; and , with the grave dignity with which [he]367-the captain did everything , [he]367-the captain relieved [her]464-a poor old woman of [her]464-a poor old woman burden , and steered along [the street]467-the street by [her]464-a poor old woman side , carrying [her]464-a poor old woman baked mutton and potatoes safely [home]306-home . This was thought very eccentric ; and it was rather expected that [he]367-the captain would pay a round of calls , on the Monday morning , to explain and apologise to [the Cranford]96-signor brunoni sense of propriety : but [he]367-the captain did no such thing : and then it was decided that [he]367-the captain was ashamed , and was keeping out of sight . In a kindly pity for [him]367-the captain , [we]469-we began to say , “ After all , the Sunday morning ’s occurrence showed great goodness of heart , ”[469-we] and it was resolved that [he]367-the captain should be comforted on [his]367-the captain next appearance amongst [us]469-we ; but , lo ! [he]367-the captain came down upon [us]469-we , untouched by any sense of shame , speaking loud and bass as ever , [his]367-the captain head thrown back , [his]367-the captain wig as jaunty and well - curled as usual , and [we]469-we were obliged to conclude [he]367-the captain had forgotten all about Sunday . [Miss Pole]89-miss pole and [Miss Jessie Brown]85-miss jessie had set up a kind of intimacy on the strength of the Shetland wool and the new knitting stitches ; so it happened that when [I]0-i went to visit [Miss Pole]89-miss pole [I]0-i saw more of [the Browns]87-the browns than [I]0-i had done while staying with [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns , who had never got over what [she]86-miss jenkyns called [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ’s disparaging remarks upon [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson as [a writer of light and agreeable fiction]470-a writer of light and agreeable fiction . [I]0-i found that [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie was seriously ill of some lingering , incurable complaint , the pain occasioned by which gave the uneasy expression to [her]85-miss jessie face that [I]0-i had taken for unmitigated crossness . [Cross]97-cross , too , [she]85-miss jessie was at times , when the nervous irritability occasioned by [her]85-miss jessie disease became past endurance . [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie bore with [her]85-miss jessie at these times , even more patiently than [she]85-miss jessie did with the bitter self - upbraidings by which they were invariably succeeded . [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie used to accuse [herself]85-miss jessie , not merely of hasty and irritable temper , but also of being the cause why [[her]85-miss jessie father]397-her father and [sister]472-sister were obliged to pinch , in order to allow [her]85-miss jessie the small luxuries which were necessaries in [her]85-miss jessie condition . [She]85-miss jessie would so fain have made sacrifices for [them]473-them , and have lightened [their]473-them cares , that the original generosity of [her]85-miss jessie disposition added acerbity to [her]85-miss jessie temper . All this was borne by [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie and [[her]85-miss jessie father]397-her father with more than placidity — with absolute tenderness . [I]0-i forgave [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie [her]85-miss jessie singing out of tune , and [her]85-miss jessie juvenility of dress , when [I]0-i saw [her]85-miss jessie at [home]306-home . [I]0-i came to perceive that [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ’s dark Brutus wig and padded coat ( alas ! too often threadbare ) were remnants of the military smartness of [his]80-captain brown youth , which [he]80-captain brown now wore unconsciously . [He]80-captain brown was [a man of infinite resources]476-a man of infinite resources , gained in [his]80-captain brown barrack experience . As [he]80-captain brown confessed , [no one]477-no one could black [his]80-captain brown boots to please [him]80-captain brown except [himself]80-captain brown ; but , indeed , [he]80-captain brown was not above saving [the little maid - servant]478-the little maid - servant ’s labours in every way — knowing , most likely , that [[his]80-captain brown daughter]479-his daughter ’s illness made [the place]480-the place a hard one . [He]80-captain brown endeavoured to make peace with [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns soon after the memorable dispute [I]0-i have named , by a present of a wooden fire - shovel ( [his]80-captain brown own making ) , having heard [her]86-miss jenkyns say how much the grating of an iron one annoyed [her]86-miss jenkyns . [She]86-miss jenkyns received the present with cool gratitude , and thanked [him]80-captain brown formally . When [he]80-captain brown was gone , [she]86-miss jenkyns bade [me]0-i put it away in [the lumber - room]481-the lumber - room ; feeling , probably , that no present from [a man who preferred [Mr Boz]94-mr boz to [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson]482-a man who preferred mr boz to dr johnson could be less jarring than an iron fire - shovel . Such was the state of things when [I]0-i left [Cranford]1-cranford and went to [Drumble]2-drumble . [I]0-i had , however , [several correspondents , who kept [me]0-i _ au fait _ as to the proceedings of [the dear little town]484-the dear little town]483-several correspondents , who kept me _ au fait _ as to the proceedings of the dear little town . There was [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , who was becoming as much absorbed in crochet as [she]89-miss pole had been once in knitting , and the burden of whose letter was something like , “ But do n’t [you]0-i forget the white worsted at Flint ’s ”[89-miss pole] of the old song ; for at the end of every sentence of news came a fresh direction as to some crochet commission which [I]0-i was to execute for [her]89-miss pole . [Miss Matilda Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns ( who did not mind being called [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , when [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns was not by ) wrote nice , kind , rambling letters , now and then venturing into an opinion of [her]86-miss jenkyns own ; but suddenly pulling [herself]86-miss jenkyns up , and either begging [me]0-i not to name what [she]86-miss jenkyns had said , as [Deborah]99-deborah thought differently , and _ [she]86-miss jenkyns _ knew , or else putting in a postscript to the effect that , since writing the above , [she]86-miss jenkyns had been talking over the subject with [Deborah]99-deborah , and was quite convinced that , etc.—(here probably followed a recantation of every opinion [she]86-miss jenkyns had given in the letter ) . Then came [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns — Debōrah , as [she]86-miss jenkyns liked [Miss Matty]98-miss matty to call [her]86-miss jenkyns , [[her]86-miss jenkyns father]397-her father having once said that the Hebrew name ought to be so pronounced . [I]0-i secretly think [she]86-miss jenkyns took [the Hebrew prophetess]486-the hebrew prophetess for [a model in character]487-a model in character ; and , indeed , [she]86-miss jenkyns was not unlike [the stern prophetess]488-the stern prophetess in some ways , making allowance , of course , for modern customs and difference in dress . [Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns wore a cravat , and a little bonnet like a jockey - cap , and altogether had the appearance of [a strong - minded woman]489-a strong - minded woman ; although [she]86-miss jenkyns would have despised the modern idea of [women]279-women being equal to [men]491-men . Equal , indeed ! [she]86-miss jenkyns knew [they]279-women were superior . But to return to [her]86-miss jenkyns letters . Everything in them was stately and grand like [herself]86-miss jenkyns . [I]0-i have been looking them over ( [dear Miss Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns , how [I]0-i honoured [her]86-miss jenkyns ! ) and [I]0-i will give an extract , more especially because it relates to [[our]492-our friend]493-our friend [Captain Brown]80-captain brown : — “ [The Honourable Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson has only just quitted [me]80-captain brown ; and , in the course of conversation , [she]78-mrs jamieson communicated to [me]80-captain brown the intelligence that [she]78-mrs jamieson had yesterday received a call from [[her]78-mrs jamieson revered husband ’s quondam friend]2084-her revered husband ’s quondam friend , [Lord Mauleverer]100-lord mauleverer . [You]2085-you will not easily conjecture what brought [his]80-captain brown lordship within [the precincts of [[our]492-our [little town]2088-little town]2087-our little town]2086-the precincts of our little town . It was to see [Captain Brown]80-captain brown , with whom , it appears , [[his]80-captain brown lordship]2089-his lordship was acquainted in the ‘ plumed wars , ’ and who had the privilege of averting destruction from [[his]80-captain brown lordship]2089-his lordship ’s head when some great peril was impending over it , off [the misnomered Cape of Good Hope]2091-the misnomered cape of good hope . [You]2085-you know [[our]492-our friend]493-our friend the Honourable [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s deficiency in the spirit of innocent curiosity , and [you]2085-you will therefore not be so much surprised when [I]80-captain brown tell [you]2085-you [she]78-mrs jamieson was quite unable to disclose to [me]80-captain brown the exact nature of the peril in question . [I]80-captain brown was anxious , [I]80-captain brown confess , to ascertain in what manner [Captain Brown]80-captain brown , with [his]80-captain brown limited establishment , could receive so distinguished [a guest]2093-a guest ; and [I]80-captain brown discovered that [[his]80-captain brown lordship]2089-his lordship retired to rest , and , let [us]492-our hope , to refreshing slumbers , at [the Angel Hotel]2095-the angel hotel ; but shared the Brunonian meals during the two days that [he]80-captain brown honoured [Cranford]96-signor brunoni with [his]80-captain brown august presence . [Mrs Johnson]101-mrs johnson , [[our]492-our [civil butcher]2097-civil butcher ’s wife]2096-our civil butcher ’s wife , informs [me]80-captain brown that [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie purchased a leg of lamb ; but , besides this , [I]80-captain brown can hear of no preparation whatever to give a suitable reception to so distinguished [a visitor]2098-a visitor . Perhaps [they]2099-they entertained [him]80-captain brown with ‘ the feast of reason and the flow of soul ’ ; and to [us]492-our , who are acquainted with [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ’s sad want of relish for ‘ [the pure wells of English]2100-the pure wells of english undefiled , ’ it may be matter for congratulation that [he]80-captain brown has had the opportunity of improving [his]80-captain brown taste by holding converse with [an elegant and refined member of the British aristocracy]2101-an elegant and refined member of the british aristocracy . But from some mundane failings who is altogether free ? ”[80-captain brown] [Miss Pole]89-miss pole and [Miss Matty]98-miss matty wrote to [me]0-i by the same post . Such a piece of news as [Lord Mauleverer]100-lord mauleverer ’s visit was not to be lost on the [Cranford]1-cranford letter - writers : [they]494-they made the most of it . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty humbly apologised for writing at the same time as [[her]98-miss matty sister]394-her sister , who was so much more capable than [she]98-miss matty to describe the honour done to [Cranford]96-signor brunoni ; but in spite of a little bad spelling , [Miss Matty]98-miss matty ’s account gave [me]0-i the best idea of the commotion occasioned by [[his]100-lord mauleverer lordship]2089-his lordship ’s visit , after it had occurred ; for , except [the people at the Angel]497-the people at the angel , [the Browns]87-the browns , [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson , and [a little lad [[his]100-lord mauleverer lordship]2089-his lordship had sworn at for driving a dirty hoop against the aristocratic legs , [I]0-i could not hear of any one with whom [[his]100-lord mauleverer lordship]2089-his lordship had held conversation]498-a little lad his lordship had sworn at for driving a dirty hoop against the aristocratic legs , i could not hear of any one with whom his lordship had held conversation . [My]0-i next visit to [Cranford]1-cranford was in the summer . There had been neither births , deaths , nor marriages since [I]0-i was there last . [Everybody]296-everybody lived in [the same house]502-the same house , and wore pretty nearly the same well - preserved , old - fashioned clothes . The greatest event was , that [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty had purchased a new carpet for [the drawing - room]503-the drawing - room . Oh , the busy work [Miss Matty]98-miss matty and [I]0-i had in chasing the sunbeams , as [they]504-they fell in an afternoon right down on this carpet through the blindless window ! [We]505-we spread newspapers over [the places]506-the places and sat down to [our]505-we book or [our]505-we work ; and , lo ! in a quarter of an hour the sun had moved , and was blazing away on a fresh spot ; and down again [we]505-we went on [our]505-we knees to alter the position of the newspapers . [We]505-we were very busy , too , one whole morning , before [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty gave [her]98-miss matty party , in following [her]98-miss matty directions , and in cutting out and stitching together pieces of newspaper so as to form little paths to every chair set for [the expected visitors]507-the expected visitors , lest [their]507-the expected visitors shoes might dirty or defile the purity of the carpet . Do [you]508-you make paper paths for [every guest]509-every guest to walk upon in [London]4-london ? [Captain Brown]80-captain brown and [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty were not very cordial to each other . The literary dispute , of which [I]0-i had seen the beginning , was a “ raw , ”[508-you] the slightest touch on which made [them]510-them wince . It was the only difference of opinion [they]510-them had ever had ; but that difference was enough . [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty could not refrain from talking at [Captain Brown]80-captain brown ; and , though [he]80-captain brown did not reply , [he]80-captain brown drummed with [his]80-captain brown fingers , which action [she]98-miss matty felt and resented as very disparaging to [Dr Johnson]91-dr johnson . [He]80-captain brown was rather ostentatious in [his]80-captain brown preference of the writings of [Mr Boz]94-mr boz ; would walk through [the streets]360-the streets so absorbed in [them]512-them that [he]80-captain brown all but ran against [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty ; and though [his]80-captain brown apologies were earnest and sincere , and though [he]80-captain brown did not , in fact , do more than startle [her]98-miss matty and [himself]80-captain brown , [she]98-miss matty owned to [me]0-i [she]98-miss matty had rather [he]80-captain brown had knocked [her]98-miss matty down , if [he]80-captain brown had only been reading a higher style of literature . [The poor , brave Captain]513-the poor , brave captain ! [he]80-captain brown looked older , and more worn , and [his]80-captain brown clothes were very threadbare . But [he]80-captain brown seemed as bright and cheerful as ever , unless [he]80-captain brown was asked about [[his]80-captain brown daughter]479-his daughter ’s health . “ [She]479-his daughter suffers a great deal , and [she]479-his daughter must suffer more : [we]516-we do what [we]516-we can to alleviate [her]479-his daughter pain;—God ’s will be done ! ”[80-captain brown] [He]80-captain brown took off [his]80-captain brown hat at these last words . [I]0-i found , from [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , that everything had been done , in fact . [A medical man , of high repute in that country neighbourhood]515-a medical man , of high repute in that country neighbourhood , had been sent for , and every injunction [he]515-a medical man , of high repute in that country neighbourhood had given was attended to , regardless of expense . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty was sure [they]516-we denied [themselves]516-we many things in order to make [the invalid]517-the invalid comfortable ; but [they]516-we never spoke about it ; and as for [Miss Jessie!—“I]102-miss jessie!—“i really think [she]479-his daughter ’s [an angel]2102-an angel , ”[102-miss jessie!—“i] said poor [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , quite overcome . “ To see [her]479-his daughter way of bearing with [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie ’s crossness , and the bright face [she]479-his daughter puts on after [she]479-his daughter ’s been sitting up a whole night and scolded above half of it , is quite beautiful . Yet [she]479-his daughter looks as neat and as ready to welcome [the Captain]367-the captain at breakfast - time as if [she]479-his daughter had been asleep in [the Queen]2104-the queen ’s bed all night . [[My]98-miss matty dear]2063-my dear ! [you]2063-my dear could never laugh at [her]479-his daughter prim little curls or [her]479-his daughter pink bows again if [you]2063-my dear saw [her]479-his daughter as [I]98-miss matty have done . ”[98-miss matty] [I]0-i could only feel very penitent , and greet [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie with double respect when [I]0-i met [her]85-miss jessie next . [She]85-miss jessie looked faded and pinched ; and [her]85-miss jessie lips began to quiver , as if [she]85-miss jessie was very weak , when [she]85-miss jessie spoke of [[her]85-miss jessie sister]394-her sister . But [she]85-miss jessie brightened , and sent back the tears that were glittering in [her]85-miss jessie pretty eyes , as [she]85-miss jessie said — “ But , to be sure , what [a town Cranford]2106-a town cranford is for kindness ! [I]85-miss jessie do n’t suppose [any one]2107-any one has a better dinner than usual cooked but the best part of all comes in a little covered basin for [[my]85-miss jessie sister]2108-my sister . [The poor people]2109-the poor people will leave [their]2109-the poor people earliest vegetables at [our]2110-our door for [her]2108-my sister . [They]2109-the poor people speak short and gruff , as if [they]2109-the poor people were ashamed of it : but [I]85-miss jessie am sure it often goes to [my]85-miss jessie heart to see [their]2109-the poor people thoughtfulness . ”[85-miss jessie] The tears now came back and overflowed ; but after a minute or two [she]85-miss jessie began to scold [herself]85-miss jessie , and ended by going away the same cheerful [Miss Jessie]85-miss jessie as ever . “ But why does not this [Lord Mauleverer]100-lord mauleverer do something for [the man who saved [his]100-lord mauleverer life]2111-the man who saved his life ? ”[519-i.] said [I.]519-i. “ Why , [you]85-miss jessie see , unless [Captain Brown]80-captain brown has some reason for it , [he]80-captain brown never speaks about being poor ; and [he]80-captain brown walked along by [[his]80-captain brown lordship]2089-his lordship looking as happy and cheerful as [a prince]2113-a prince ; and as [they]2109-the poor people never called attention to [their]2109-the poor people dinner by apologies , and as [Miss Brown]85-miss jessie was better that day , and all seemed bright , [I]519-i. daresay [[his]80-captain brown lordship]2089-his lordship never knew how much care there was in the background . [He]80-captain brown did send game in the winter pretty often , but now [he]80-captain brown is gone abroad . ”[519-i.] [I]0-i had often occasion to notice the use that was made of fragments and small opportunities in [Cranford]1-cranford ; the rose - leaves that were gathered ere they fell to make into a potpourri for someone who had [no garden]520-no garden ; the little bundles of lavender flowers sent to strew the drawers of [some town - dweller]521-some town - dweller , or to burn in [the chamber of [some invalid]523-some invalid]522-the chamber of some invalid . Things that many would despise , and actions which it seemed scarcely worth while to perform , were all attended to in [Cranford]1-cranford . [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty stuck an apple full of cloves , to be heated and smell pleasantly in [[Miss Brown]85-miss jessie ’s room]524-miss brown ’s room ; and as [she]98-miss matty put in each clove [she]98-miss matty uttered a Johnsonian sentence . Indeed , [she]98-miss matty never could think of [the Browns]87-the browns without talking [Johnson]91-dr johnson ; and , as [they]87-the browns were seldom absent from [her]98-miss matty thoughts just then , [I]0-i heard many a rolling , three - piled sentence . [Captain Brown]80-captain brown called one day to thank [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty for many little kindnesses , which [I]0-i did not know until then that [she]98-miss matty had rendered . [He]80-captain brown had suddenly become like [an old man]525-an old man ; [his]80-captain brown deep bass voice had a quavering in it , [his]80-captain brown eyes looked dim , and the lines on [his]80-captain brown face were deep . [He]80-captain brown did not — could not — speak cheerfully of [[his]80-captain brown daughter]479-his daughter ’s state , but [he]80-captain brown talked with manly , pious resignation , and not much . Twice over [he]80-captain brown said , “ What [Jessie]85-miss jessie has been to [us]528-us , [God]103-god only knows ! ”[80-captain brown] and after the second time , [he]80-captain brown got up hastily , shook hands all round without speaking , and left [the room]370-the room . That afternoon [we]528-us perceived [little groups in [the street]467-the street]529-little groups in the street , all listening with faces aghast to some tale or other . [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty wondered what could be the matter for some time before [she]98-miss matty took the undignified step of sending [Jenny]104-jenny out to inquire . [Jenny]104-jenny came back with a white face of terror . “ Oh , [ma’am]2067-ma’am ! Oh , [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty , [ma’am]2067-ma’am !
