Nor do [I]0-i think [Miss Barker]81-miss barker perceived it ; for , putting aside the little circumstance that [she]81-miss barker was not so young as [she]81-miss barker had been , [she]81-miss barker was very much absorbed in [her]81-miss barker errand , which [she]81-miss barker delivered [herself]81-miss barker of with an oppressive modesty that found vent in endless apologies . [Miss Betty Barker]81-miss barker was [the daughter of [the old clerk at [Cranford]1-cranford who had officiated in [Mr Jenkyns]159-mr jenkyns ’s time]2505-the old clerk at cranford who had officiated in mr jenkyns ’s time]2504-the daughter of the old clerk at cranford who had officiated in mr jenkyns ’s time . [She]81-miss barker and [[her]81-miss barker sister]394-her sister had had pretty good situations as [ladies ’ maids]2507-ladies ’ maids , and had saved money enough to set up [[a milliner]2508-a milliner ’s shop]2509-a milliner ’s shop , which had been patronised by [the ladies in [the neighbourhood]2511-the neighbourhood]2510-the ladies in the neighbourhood . [Lady Arley]160-lady arley , for instance , would occasionally give [Miss Barkers]161-miss barkers the pattern of an old cap of hers , which [they]2512-they immediately copied and circulated among the _ élite _ of [Cranford]1-cranford . [I]0-i say the _ élite _ , for [Miss Barkers]161-miss barkers had caught the trick of [the place]480-the place , and piqued [themselves]161-miss barkers upon [their]2512-they “[0-i] aristocratic connection . ” [They]2512-they would not sell [their]2512-they caps and ribbons to [anyone without a pedigree]2514-anyone without a pedigree . [[Many a farmer]2515-many a farmer ’s wife]2516-many a farmer ’s wife or [daughter]2517-daughter turned away huffed from [[Miss Barkers]161-miss barkers ’ select millinery]2518-miss barkers ’ select millinery , and went rather to [the universal shop]2519-the universal shop , where the profits of brown soap and moist sugar enabled [the proprietor]2520-the proprietor to go straight to ( [Paris]22-paris , [he]2520-the proprietor said , until [he]2520-the proprietor found [[his]2520-the proprietor customers]2521-his customers too patriotic and [John Bullish]162-john bullish to wear what [the Mounseers]163-the mounseers wore ) [London]4-london , where , as [he]2520-the proprietor often told [[his]2520-the proprietor customers]2521-his customers , [Queen Adelaide]164-queen adelaide had appeared , only the very week before , in a cap exactly like the one [he]2520-the proprietor showed [them]2521-his customers , trimmed with yellow and blue ribbons , and had been complimented by [King William]165-king william on the becoming nature of [her]164-queen adelaide head - dress . [Miss Barkers]161-miss barkers , who confined [themselves]161-miss barkers to truth , and did not approve of [miscellaneous customers]2523-miscellaneous customers , throve notwithstanding . [They]2521-his customers were self - denying , [good people]2524-good people . Many a time have [I]0-i seen [the eldest of [them]2521-his customers]2525-the eldest of them ( [she]2525-the eldest of them that had been maid to [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ) carrying out some delicate mess to [a poor person]2526-a poor person . [They]2521-his customers only aped [their]2521-his customers betters in having “[0-i] nothing to do ” with the class immediately below [theirs]2521-his customers . And when [Miss Barker]81-miss barker died , [their]2521-his customers profits and income were found to be such that [Miss Betty]81-miss barker was justified in shutting up [shop]2527-shop and retiring from business . [She]81-miss barker also ( as [I]0-i think [I]0-i have before said ) set up [her]81-miss barker cow ; a mark of respectability in [Cranford]1-cranford almost as decided as setting up a gig is among [some people]2160-some people . [She]81-miss barker dressed finer than [any lady in [Cranford]1-cranford]2529-any lady in cranford ; and [we]2530-we did not wonder at it ; for it was understood that [she]81-miss barker was wearing out all the bonnets and caps and outrageous ribbons which had once formed [her]81-miss barker stock - in - trade . It was five or six years since [she]81-miss barker had given up [shop]2527-shop , so in [any other place than [Cranford]1-cranford]2532-any other place than cranford [her]81-miss barker dress might have been considered _ passée _ . And now [Miss Betty Barker]81-miss barker had called to invite [Miss Matty]98-miss matty to tea at [[her]81-miss barker house]600-her house on the following Tuesday . [She]81-miss barker gave [me]0-i also an impromptu invitation , as [I]0-i happened to be [a visitor]2098-a visitor — though [I]0-i could see [she]81-miss barker had a little fear lest , since [[my]0-i father]2082-my father had gone to live in [Drumble]2-drumble , [he]2082-my father might have engaged in that “[0-i] horrid cotton trade , ” and so dragged [[his]2082-my father family]833-his family down out of “[0-i] aristocratic society . ” [She]81-miss barker prefaced this invitation with so many apologies that [she]81-miss barker quite excited [my]1098-her curiosity . “[1098-her] [Her]1098-her presumption ” was to be excused . What had [she]81-miss barker been doing ? [She]81-miss barker seemed so overpowered by it [I]1098-her could only think that [she]81-miss barker had been writing to [Queen Adelaide]164-queen adelaide to ask for a receipt for washing lace ; but the act which [she]81-miss barker so characterised was only an invitation [she]81-miss barker had carried to [[[her]81-miss barker sister]394-her sister ’s former mistress]2538-her sister ’s former mistress , [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson . “[1098-her] [Her]1098-her former occupation considered , could [Miss Matty]98-miss matty excuse the liberty ? ” Ah ! thought [I]98-miss matty , [she]81-miss barker has found out that double cap , and is going to rectify [Miss Matty]98-miss matty ’s head - dress . No ! it was simply to extend [her]81-miss barker invitation to [Miss Matty]98-miss matty and to [me]98-miss matty . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty bowed acceptance ; and [I]98-miss matty wondered that , in the graceful action , [she]98-miss matty did not feel the unusual weight and extraordinary height of [her]98-miss matty head - dress . But [I]98-miss matty do not think [she]98-miss matty did , for [she]98-miss matty recovered [her]98-miss matty balance , and went on talking to [Miss Betty]81-miss barker in a kind , condescending manner , very different from the fidgety way [she]98-miss matty would have had if [she]98-miss matty had suspected how singular [her]98-miss matty appearance was . “[98-miss matty] [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson is coming , [I]0-i think [you]0-i said ? ” asked [Miss Matty]98-miss matty . “[0-i] Yes . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson most kindly and condescendingly said [she]78-mrs jamieson would be happy to come . One little stipulation [she]78-mrs jamieson made , that [she]78-mrs jamieson should bring [Carlo]166-carlo . [I]0-i told [her]78-mrs jamieson that if [I]0-i had a weakness , it was for dogs . ” “[0-i] And [Miss Pole]89-miss pole ? ” questioned [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , who was thinking of [her]89-miss pole pool at [Preference]40-preference , in which [Carlo]166-carlo would not be available as [a partner]2539-a partner . “[89-miss pole] [I]0-i am going to ask [Miss Pole]89-miss pole . [I]0-i thought , in fact , of going to [her]77-mrs forrester before [I]0-i went to [Miss Pole]89-miss pole . Although [her]77-mrs forrester circumstances are changed , [madam]2237-madam , [she]77-mrs forrester was born [a Tyrrell]1105-a tyrrell , and [we]1106-we can never forget [her]77-mrs forrester alliance to [the Bigges]167-the bigges , of [Bigelow Hall]41-bigelow hall . ” [Miss Matty]98-miss matty cared much more for the little circumstance of [her]77-mrs forrester being [a very good card - player]2540-a very good card - player . “[167-the bigges] [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam — [I]0-i suppose ” — “[168-mrs fitz - adam] No , [madam]2237-madam . [I]0-i must draw a line somewhere . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson would not , [I]0-i think , like to meet [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam . [I]0-i have the greatest respect for [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam — but [I]0-i can not think [her]78-mrs jamieson fit society for [such ladies as [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson and [Miss Matilda Jenkyns]86-miss jenkyns]1108-such ladies as mrs jamieson and miss matilda jenkyns . ” [Miss Betty Barker]81-miss barker bowed low to [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , and pursed up [her]0-i mouth . [She]0-i looked at [me]0-i with sidelong dignity , as much as to say , although [a retired milliner]2541-a retired milliner , [she]0-i was [no democrat]2542-no democrat , and understood the difference of ranks . “[0-i] May [I]0-i beg [you]1109-you to come as near half - past six to [[my]0-i little dwelling]1110-my little dwelling , as possible , [Miss Matilda]86-miss jenkyns ? [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson dines at five , but has kindly promised not to delay [her]78-mrs jamieson visit beyond that time — half - past six . ” And with a swimming curtsey [Miss Betty Barker]81-miss barker took [her]0-i leave . [My]81-miss barker prophetic soul foretold a visit that afternoon from [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , who usually came to call on [Miss Matilda]86-miss jenkyns [after any event — or indeed in sight of any event]2543-after any event — or indeed in sight of any event — to talk it over with [her]86-miss jenkyns . “[81-miss barker] [Miss Betty]81-miss barker told [me]0-i it was to be a choice and select few , ” said [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , as [she]89-miss pole and [Miss Matty]98-miss matty compared notes . “[81-miss barker] Yes , so [she]81-miss barker said . Not even [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam . ” Now [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam was [the widowed sister of [the Cranford surgeon]2545-the cranford surgeon , whom [I]81-miss barker have named before]2544-the widowed sister of the cranford surgeon , whom i have named before . [[Their]2546-their parents]2547-their parents were [respectable farmers]2548-respectable farmers , content with [their]2546-their station . The name of [these good people]2549-these good people was [Hoggins]138-maria . [Mr Hoggins]105-mr hoggins was [the Cranford doctor]2550-the cranford doctor now ; [we]2551-we disliked the name and considered it coarse ; but , as [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty said , if [he]105-mr hoggins changed it to [Piggins]169-piggins it would not be much better . [We]2551-we had hoped to discover a relationship between [him]105-mr hoggins and [that Marchioness of [Exeter]42-exeter whose name was [Molly Hoggins]138-maria]138-maria ; but [the man]424-the man , careless of [his]105-mr hoggins own interests , utterly ignored and denied any such relationship , although , as [dear Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty had said , [he]105-mr hoggins had [a sister called [Mary]138-maria]2553-a sister called mary , and the same Christian names were very apt to run in [families]2554-families . Soon after [Miss Mary Hoggins]109-mary married [Mr Fitz - Adam]170-mr fitz - adam , [she]109-mary disappeared from [the neighbourhood]2511-the neighbourhood for many years . [She]109-mary did not move in a sphere in [Cranford]1-cranford society sufficiently high to make any of [us]2551-we care to know what [Mr Fitz - Adam]170-mr fitz - adam was . [He]170-mr fitz - adam died and was gathered to [[his]170-mr fitz - adam fathers]2556-his fathers without [our]2551-we ever having thought about [him]170-mr fitz - adam at all . And then [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam reappeared in [Cranford]1-cranford ( “[81-miss barker] as bold as a lion , ” [Miss Pole]89-miss pole said ) , [a well - to - do widow]2557-a well - to - do widow , dressed in rustling black silk , so soon after [[her]1111-her husband]601-her husband ’s death that poor [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty was justified in the remark [she]1111-her made , that “[81-miss barker] bombazine would have shown a deeper sense of [her]1111-her loss . ” [I]81-miss barker remember [the convocation of [ladies who assembled to decide whether or not]2560-ladies who assembled to decide whether or not [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam should be called upon by [the old blue - blooded inhabitants of [Cranford]1-cranford]2561-the old blue - blooded inhabitants of cranford]2559-the convocation of ladies who assembled to decide whether or not mrs fitz - adam should be called upon by the old blue - blooded inhabitants of cranford . [She]168-mrs fitz - adam had taken [a large rambling house]2562-a large rambling house , which had been usually considered to confer a patent of gentility upon [[its]2562-a large rambling house tenant]2563-its tenant , because , once upon a time , seventy or eighty years before , [the spinster daughter of [an earl]2565-an earl]2564-the spinster daughter of an earl had resided in [it]2562-a large rambling house . [I]81-miss barker am not sure if the inhabiting [this house]2566-this house was not also believed to convey some unusual power of intellect ; for [[the earl]2567-the earl ’s daughter]2568-the earl ’s daughter , [Lady Jane]171-lady jane , had [a sister]2569-a sister , [Lady Anne]172-lady anne , who had married [a general officer in the time of the American war]2570-a general officer in the time of the american war , and [this general officer]2571-this general officer had written one or two comedies , which were still acted on the [London]4-london boards , and which , when [we]2572-we saw them advertised , made [us]2572-we all draw up , and feel that [Drury Lane]173-drury lane was paying a very pretty compliment to [Cranford]1-cranford . Still , it was not at all a settled thing that [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam was to be visited , when [dear Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty died ; and , with [her]168-mrs fitz - adam , something of the clear knowledge of the strict code of gentility went out too . As [Miss Pole]89-miss pole observed , “[81-miss barker] As [most of [the ladies of good family in [Cranford]1-cranford]1113-the ladies of good family in cranford]1112-most of the ladies of good family in cranford were [elderly spinsters]1114-elderly spinsters , or [widows without [children]1116-children]1115-widows without children , if [we]1117-we did not relax a little , and become less exclusive , by - and - by [we]1117-we should have [no society]1118-no society at all . ” [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester continued on the same side . “[1119-she] [She]1119-she had always understood that [Fitz]168-mrs fitz - adam meant something aristocratic ; there was [Fitz - Roy]174-fitz - roy — [she]1119-she thought that [some of [[the King]165-king william ’s children]1121-the king ’s children]1120-some of the king ’s children had been called [Fitz - Roy]174-fitz - roy ; and there was [Fitz - Clarence]175-fitz - clarence , now — [they]175-fitz - clarence were the children of dear good [King William the Fourth]165-king william . [Fitz - Adam!—it]176-fitz - adam!—it was a pretty name , and [she]1119-she thought it very probably meant ‘ [Child of [Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam]1122-child of adam . ’ [No one]477-no one , who had not some good blood in [their]477-no one veins , would dare to be called [Fitz]168-mrs fitz - adam ; there was a deal in a name — [she]1119-she had had [a cousin]698-a cousin who spelt [his]698-a cousin name with two little ffs — ffoulkes — and [he]698-a cousin always looked down upon capital letters and said they belonged to [lately - invented families]1125-lately - invented families . [She]1119-she had been afraid [he]698-a cousin would die [a bachelor]2224-a bachelor , [he]698-a cousin was so very choice . When [he]698-a cousin met with [a Mrs ffarringdon]1127-a mrs ffarringdon , at [a watering - place]1128-a watering - place , [he]698-a cousin took to [her]1127-a mrs ffarringdon immediately ; and [a very pretty genteel woman]1129-a very pretty genteel woman [she]1127-a mrs ffarringdon was — [a widow , with a very good fortune]1130-a widow , with a very good fortune ; and ‘ [[my]0-i cousin]2212-my cousin , ’ [Mr ffoulkes]1132-mr ffoulkes , married [her]1127-a mrs ffarringdon ; and it was all owing to [her]1127-a mrs ffarringdon two little ffs . ” [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam did not stand a chance of meeting with [a Mr Fitz]170-mr fitz - adam - anything in [Cranford]1-cranford , so that could not have been [her]168-mrs fitz - adam motive for settling [there]289-there . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty thought it might have been the hope of being admitted into the society of [the place]480-the place , which would certainly be a very agreeable rise for _ ci - devant _ [Miss Hoggins]109-mary ; and if this had been [her]168-mrs fitz - adam hope it would be cruel to disappoint [her]168-mrs fitz - adam . So [everybody]296-everybody called upon [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam — everybody but [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson , who used to show how honourable [she]78-mrs jamieson was by never seeing [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam when [they]2576-they met at the [Cranford]1-cranford parties . There would be [only eight or ten ladies in [the room]370-the room]2577-only eight or ten ladies in the room , and [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam was the largest of all , and [she]168-mrs fitz - adam invariably used to stand up when [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson came in , and curtsey very low to [her]168-mrs fitz - adam whenever [she]168-mrs fitz - adam turned in [her]168-mrs fitz - adam direction — so low , in fact , that [I]177-peggy think [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson must have looked at the wall above [her]168-mrs fitz - adam , for [she]78-mrs jamieson never moved a muscle of [her]78-mrs jamieson face , no more than if [she]78-mrs jamieson had not seen [her]168-mrs fitz - adam . Still [Mrs Fitz - Adam]168-mrs fitz - adam persevered . The spring evenings were getting bright and long when [three or four ladies in calashes]2579-three or four ladies in calashes met at [Miss Barker]81-miss barker ’s door . Do [you]2580-you know what a calash is ? It is a covering worn over caps , not unlike the heads fastened on old - fashioned gigs ; but sometimes it is not quite so large . This kind of head - gear always made an awful impression on [[the children]2581-the children in [Cranford]1-cranford]2582-the children in cranford ; and now [two or three]2583-two or three left off [their]2583-two or three play in [the quiet sunny little street]2584-the quiet sunny little street , and gathered in wondering silence round [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , and [myself]177-peggy . [We]2585-we were silent too , so that [we]2585-we could hear loud , suppressed whispers inside [[Miss Barker]81-miss barker ’s house]2586-miss barker ’s house : “[177-peggy] Wait , [Peggy]177-peggy ! wait till [I]0-i ’ve run [upstairs]340-upstairs and washed [my]0-i hands . When [I]0-i cough , open the door ; [I]0-i ’ll not be a minute . ” And , true enough it was not a minute before [we]2585-we heard a noise , between a sneeze and a crow ; on which the door flew open . Behind it stood [a round - eyed maiden]2587-a round - eyed maiden , all aghast at [the honourable company of calashes , who marched in without a word]2588-the honourable company of calashes , who marched in without a word . [She]2587-a round - eyed maiden recovered presence of mind enough to usher [us]2585-we into [a small room]2589-a small room , which had been [the shop]716-the shop , but was now converted into [a temporary dressing - room]2591-a temporary dressing - room . There [we]2585-we unpinned and shook [ourselves]2585-we , and arranged [our]2585-we features before the glass into a sweet and gracious company - face ; and then , bowing backwards with “[0-i] After [you]177-peggy , [ma’am]2067-ma’am , ” [we]2585-we allowed [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester to take [precedence]2592-precedence up the narrow staircase that led to [[Miss Barker]81-miss barker ’s drawing - room]2593-miss barker ’s drawing - room . There [she]2587-a round - eyed maiden sat , as stately and composed as though [we]2585-we had never heard that odd - sounding cough , from which [her]2587-a round - eyed maiden throat must have been even then sore and rough . [Kind , gentle , shabbily - dressed [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester]2594-kind , gentle , shabbily - dressed mrs forrester was immediately conducted to the second place of honour — a seat arranged something like [[Prince Albert]178-prince albert ’s]2595-prince albert ’s near [the Queen’s]2596-the queen’s — good , but not so good . [The place of pre - eminence]2597-the place of pre - eminence was , of course , reserved for [the Honourable Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson , who presently came panting up the stairs — [Carlo]166-carlo rushing round [her]2587-a round - eyed maiden on [her]2587-a round - eyed maiden progress , as if [he]166-carlo meant to trip [her]2587-a round - eyed maiden up . And now [Miss Betty Barker]81-miss barker was [a proud and happy woman]2598-a proud and happy woman ! [She]81-miss barker stirred the fire , and shut the door , and sat as near to it as [she]81-miss barker could , quite on the edge of [her]81-miss barker chair . When [Peggy]177-peggy came in , tottering under the weight of the tea - tray , [I]177-peggy noticed that [Miss Barker]81-miss barker was sadly afraid lest [Peggy]177-peggy should not keep [her]177-peggy distance sufficiently . [She]177-peggy and [[her]177-peggy mistress]341-her mistress were on very familiar terms in [their]2600-their every - day intercourse , and [Peggy]177-peggy wanted now to make several little confidences to [her]177-peggy , which [Miss Barker]81-miss barker was on thorns to hear , but which [she]177-peggy thought it [her]177-peggy duty , as [a lady]677-a lady , to repress . So [she]177-peggy turned away from all [Peggy]177-peggy ’s asides and signs ; but [she]177-peggy made one or two very malapropos answers to what was said ; and at last , seized with a bright idea , [she]177-peggy exclaimed , “[177-peggy] [Poor , sweet Carlo]166-carlo ! [I]0-i ’m forgetting [him]166-carlo . Come [downstairs]1135-downstairs with [me]0-i , [poor ittie doggie]1136-poor ittie doggie , and it shall have [its]166-carlo tea , it shall ! ” In a few minutes [she]177-peggy returned , bland and benignant as before ; but [I]166-carlo thought [she]177-peggy had forgotten to give [the “[166-carlo] poor ittie doggie]2602-the “ poor ittie doggie ” anything to eat , judging by the avidity with which [he]2602-the “ poor ittie doggie swallowed down chance pieces of cake . The tea - tray was abundantly loaded — [I]166-carlo was pleased to see it , [I]166-carlo was so hungry ; but [I]166-carlo was afraid [the ladies present]2603-the ladies present might think it vulgarly heaped up . [I]166-carlo know [they]2603-the ladies present would have done at [[their]2603-the ladies present own houses]2604-their own houses ; but somehow the heaps disappeared here . [I]166-carlo saw [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson eating seed - cake , slowly and considerately , as [she]78-mrs jamieson did everything ; and [I]166-carlo was rather surprised , for [I]166-carlo knew [she]78-mrs jamieson had told [us]2605-us , on the occasion of [her]78-mrs jamieson last party , that [she]78-mrs jamieson never had it in [[her]78-mrs jamieson house]600-her house , it reminded [her]78-mrs jamieson so much of scented soap . [She]78-mrs jamieson always gave [us]2605-us Savoy biscuits . However , [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson was kindly indulgent to [Miss Barker]81-miss barker ’s want of knowledge of the customs of high life ; and , to spare [her]78-mrs jamieson feelings , ate three large pieces of seed - cake , with a placid , ruminating expression of countenance , not unlike a cow ’s . After tea there was some little demur and difficulty . [We]2605-us were six in number ; four could play at Preference , and for the other two there was [Cribbage]179-cribbage . But all , except [myself]166-carlo ( [I]166-carlo was rather afraid of [the Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies at cards , for it was the most earnest and serious business [they]305-the cranford ladies ever engaged in ) , were anxious to be of [[the “[166-carlo] pool . ”]2608-the “ pool . ”]2608-the “ pool . ” Even [Miss Barker]81-miss barker , while declaring [she]81-miss barker did not know [Spadille]180-spadille from [Manille]181-manille , was evidently hankering to take a hand . The dilemma was soon put an end to by a singular kind of noise . If [[a baron]2610-a baron ’s daughter - in - law]2611-a baron ’s daughter - in - law could ever be supposed to snore , [I]166-carlo should have said [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson did so then ; for , overcome by the heat of [the room]370-the room , and inclined to doze by nature , the temptation of that very comfortable arm - chair had been too much for [her]78-mrs jamieson , and [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson was nodding . Once or twice [she]78-mrs jamieson opened [her]78-mrs jamieson eyes with an effort , and calmly but unconsciously smiled upon [us]2613-us ; but by - and - by , even [her]78-mrs jamieson benevolence was not equal to this exertion , and [she]78-mrs jamieson was sound asleep . [ Picture : The temptation of the comfortable arm - chair had been too much for [her]78-mrs jamieson ] “[166-carlo] It is very gratifying to [me]0-i , ” whispered [Miss Barker]81-miss barker at the card - table to [[her]0-i three opponents]2614-her three opponents , whom , notwithstanding [her]0-i ignorance of the game , [she]0-i was “[2218-ladies] basting ” most unmercifully—“very[2218-ladies] gratifying indeed , to see how completely [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson feels at [home]306-home in [[my]0-i poor little dwelling]1138-my poor little dwelling ; [she]78-mrs jamieson could not have paid [me]0-i a greater compliment . ” [Miss Barker]81-miss barker provided [me]78-mrs jamieson with some literature in the shape of three or four handsomely - bound fashion - books ten or twelve years old , observing , as [she]81-miss barker put a little table and a candle for [my]78-mrs jamieson especial benefit , that [she]81-miss barker knew [young people]2615-young people liked to look at pictures . [Carlo]166-carlo lay and snorted , and started at [[his]166-carlo mistress]2616-his mistress ’s feet . [He]166-carlo , too , was quite at [home]306-home . The card - table was an animated scene to watch ; [four ladies]2618-four ladies ’ heads , with niddle - noddling caps , all nearly meeting over the middle of the table in [their]2618-four ladies eagerness to whisper quick enough and loud enough : and every now and then came [Miss Barker]81-miss barker ’s “[78-mrs jamieson] Hush , [ladies]2218-ladies ! if [you]2218-ladies please , hush ! [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson is asleep . ” It was very difficult to steer clear between [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester ’s deafness and [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s sleepiness . But [Miss Barker]81-miss barker managed [her]81-miss barker arduous task well . [She]81-miss barker repeated the whisper to [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester , distorting [her]81-miss barker face considerably , in order to show , by the motions of [her]81-miss barker lips , what was said ; and then [she]81-miss barker smiled kindly all round at [us]2619-we , and murmured to [herself]81-miss barker , “[78-mrs jamieson] Very gratifying , indeed ; [I]0-i wish [[my]0-i poor sister]1140-my poor sister had been alive to see this day . ” Presently the door was thrown wide open ; [Carlo]166-carlo started to [his]166-carlo feet , with a loud snapping bark , and [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson awoke : or , perhaps , [she]78-mrs jamieson had not been asleep — as [she]78-mrs jamieson said almost directly , [the room]370-the room had been so light [she]78-mrs jamieson had been glad to keep [her]78-mrs jamieson eyes shut , but had been listening with great interest to all [our]2619-we amusing and agreeable conversation . [Peggy]177-peggy came in once more , red with importance . Another tray ! “[1140-my poor sister] Oh , gentility ! ” thought [I]1140-my poor sister , “[1140-my poor sister] can [you]1141-you endure this last shock ? ” For [Miss Barker]81-miss barker had ordered ( nay , [I]1140-my poor sister doubt not , prepared , although [she]81-miss barker did say , “[1140-my poor sister] Why , [Peggy]177-peggy , what have [you]177-peggy brought [us]1142-us ? ” and looked pleasantly surprised at the unexpected pleasure ) all sorts of good things for supper — scalloped oysters , potted lobsters , jelly , a dish called “[177-peggy] little Cupids ” ( which was in great favour with [the Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies , although too expensive to be given , except on solemn and state occasions — macaroons sopped in brandy , [I]177-peggy should have called it , if [I]177-peggy had not known its more refined and classical name ) . In short , [we]2619-we were evidently to be feasted with all that was sweetest and best ; and [we]2619-we thought it better to submit graciously , even at the cost of [our]2619-we gentility — which never ate suppers in general , but which , like [most non - supper - eaters]2622-most non - supper - eaters , was particularly hungry on all special occasions . [Miss Barker]81-miss barker , in [her]81-miss barker former sphere , had , [I]177-peggy daresay , been made acquainted with the beverage [they]2623-they call cherry - brandy . [We]2619-we none of [us]2619-we had ever seen such a thing , and rather shrank back when [she]81-miss barker proffered it us—“just[177-peggy] a little , leetle glass , [ladies]2218-ladies ; after the oysters and lobsters , [you]2218-ladies know . Shell - fish are sometimes thought not very wholesome . ” [We]2619-we all shook [our]2619-we heads like [female mandarins]2624-female mandarins ; but , at last , [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson suffered [herself]78-mrs jamieson to be persuaded , and [we]2619-we followed [her]81-miss barker lead . It was not exactly unpalatable , though so hot and so strong that [we]2619-we thought [ourselves]2619-we bound to give evidence that [we]2619-we were not accustomed to such things by coughing terribly — almost as strangely as [Miss Barker]81-miss barker had done , before [we]2619-we were admitted by [Peggy]177-peggy . “[2218-ladies] It ’s very strong , ” said [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , as [she]0-i put down [her]0-i empty glass ; “[0-i] [I]0-i do believe there ’s spirit in it . ” “[0-i] Only a little drop — just necessary to make it keep , ” said [Miss Barker]81-miss barker . “[0-i] [You]2218-ladies know [we]1144-we put brandy - pepper over [our]1144-we preserves to make them keep . [I]0-i often feel tipsy [myself]0-i from eating damson tart . ” [I]0-i question whether damson tart would have opened [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s heart as the cherry - brandy did ; but [she]78-mrs jamieson told [us]2619-we of a coming event , respecting which [she]78-mrs jamieson had been quite silent till that moment . “[0-i] [[My]0-i sister - in - law]1145-my sister - in - law , [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire , is coming to stay with [me]0-i . ” There was a chorus of “[182-lady glenmire] Indeed ! ” and then a pause . [Each one]2625-each one rapidly reviewed [her]78-mrs jamieson wardrobe , as to its fitness to appear in the presence of [[a baron]2610-a baron ’s widow]2627-a baron ’s widow ; for , of course , a series of small festivals were always held in [Cranford]1-cranford on the arrival of [a visitor]2098-a visitor at any of [[[our]2619-we friends]2062-our friends ’ houses]2630-our friends ’ houses . [We]2619-we felt very pleasantly excited on the present occasion . Not long after this [the maids]2631-the maids and the lanterns were announced . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson had the sedan - chair , which had squeezed itself into [[Miss Barker]81-miss barker ’s narrow lobby]2632-miss barker ’s narrow lobby with some difficulty , and most literally “[0-i] stopped the way . ” It required some skilful manœuvring on the part of [the old chairmen]2633-the old chairmen ( [shoemakers]2634-shoemakers by day , but when summoned to carry [the sedan]2635-the sedan dressed up in a strange old livery — long great - coats , with small capes , coeval with [the sedan]2635-the sedan , and similar to the dress of the class in [Hogarth]183-hogarth ’s pictures ) to edge , and back , and try at it again , and finally to succeed in carrying [their]2633-the old chairmen burden out of [Miss Barker]81-miss barker ’s front door . Then [we]2619-we heard [their]2633-the old chairmen quick pit - a - pat along [the quiet little street]2637-the quiet little street as [we]2619-we put on [our]2619-we calashes and pinned up [our]2619-we gowns ; [Miss Barker]81-miss barker hovering about [us]2619-we with offers of help , which , if [she]81-miss barker had not remembered [her]81-miss barker former occupation , and wished [us]2619-we to forget it , would have been much more pressing . CHAPTER VIII . “[0-i] [[YOUR]1146-you LADYSHIP]1147-your ladyship ” EARLY the next morning — directly after twelve — [Miss Pole]89-miss pole made [her]89-miss pole appearance at [Miss Matty]98-miss matty ’s . Some very trifling piece of business was alleged as a reason for the call ; but there was evidently something behind . At last out it came . “[0-i] By the way , [you]1146-you ’ll think [I]0-i ’m strangely ignorant ; but , do [you]1146-you really know , [I]0-i am puzzled how [we]1148-we ought to address [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire . Do [you]1146-you say , ‘ [[Your]1146-you Ladyship]1147-your ladyship , ’ where [you]1146-you would say ‘ [you]1146-you ’ to [a common person]1150-a common person ? [I]0-i have been puzzling all morning ; and are [we]1148-we to say ‘ [[My]0-i Lady]1151-my lady , ’ instead of ‘ [Ma’am]184-ma’am ? ’ Now [you]1146-you knew [Lady Arley]160-lady arley — will [you]1146-you kindly tell [me]0-i the most correct way of speaking to [the peerage]1152-the peerage ? ” [Poor Miss Matty]98-miss matty ! [she]98-miss matty took off [her]98-miss matty spectacles and [she]98-miss matty put them on again — but how [Lady Arley]160-lady arley was addressed , [she]98-miss matty could not remember . “[1146-you] It is so long ago , ” [she]98-miss matty said . “[2179-dear] [Dear]2179-dear ! dear ! how stupid [I]0-i am ! [I]0-i do n’t think [I]0-i ever saw [her]160-lady arley more than twice . [I]0-i know [we]1154-we used to call [Sir Peter]121-peter , ‘ Sir Peter’—but [he]121-peter came much oftener to see [us]1154-we than [Lady Arley]160-lady arley did . [Deborah]99-deborah would have known in a minute . ‘ [My]0-i lady’—‘your ladyship . ’ It sounds very strange , and as if it was not natural . [I]0-i never thought of it before ; but , now [you]1155-you have named it , [I]0-i am all in a puzzle . ” It was very certain [Miss Pole]89-miss pole would obtain no wise decision from [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , who got more bewildered every moment , and more perplexed as to etiquettes of address . “[1155-you] Well , [I]0-i really think , ” said [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , “[0-i] [I]0-i had better just go and tell [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester about [our]1154-we little difficulty . [One]2460-one sometimes grows nervous ; and yet one would not have [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire think [we]1154-we were quite ignorant of the etiquettes of high life in [Cranford]1-cranford . ” “[182-lady glenmire] And will [you]1155-you just step in here , dear [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , as [you]1155-you come back , please , and tell [me]0-i what [you]1155-you decide upon ? Whatever [you]1155-you and [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester fix upon , will be quite right , [I]0-i ’m sure . ‘ [Lady Arley]160-lady arley , ’ ‘ [Sir Peter]121-peter , ’ ” said [Miss Matty]98-miss matty to [herself]98-miss matty , trying to recall the old forms of words . “[121-peter] Who is [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire ? ” asked [I.]0-i “[182-lady glenmire] Oh , [she]182-lady glenmire ’s [the widow of [Mr Jamieson]185-mr jamieson]1157-the widow of mr jamieson — that ’s [[Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s late husband]1158-mrs jamieson ’s late husband , [you]1155-you know — [widow of [[his]185-mr jamieson eldest brother]1160-his eldest brother]1159-widow of his eldest brother . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson was a [Miss Walker]186-miss walker , [daughter of [Governor Walker]187-governor walker]1161-daughter of governor walker . ‘ [[Your]1155-you ladyship]1147-your ladyship . ’ [[My]0-i dear]2063-my dear , if [they]1164-they fix on that way of speaking , [you]1155-you must just let [me]0-i practice a little on [you]1155-you first , for [I]0-i shall feel so foolish and hot saying it the first time to [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire . ” It was really a relief to [Miss Matty]98-miss matty when [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson came on a very unpolite errand . [I]182-lady glenmire notice that [apathetic people]2638-apathetic people have more quiet impertinence than [others]838-others ; and [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson came now to insinuate pretty plainly that [she]78-mrs jamieson did not particularly wish that [the Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies should call upon [[her]78-mrs jamieson sister - in - law]2641-her sister - in - law . [I]182-lady glenmire can hardly say how [she]78-mrs jamieson made this clear ; for [I]182-lady glenmire grew very indignant and warm , while with slow deliberation [she]78-mrs jamieson was explaining [her]78-mrs jamieson wishes to [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , who , [a true lady]2642-a true lady [herself]98-miss matty , could hardly understand the feeling which made [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson wish to appear to [[her]78-mrs jamieson noble sister - in - law]2643-her noble sister - in - law as if [she]78-mrs jamieson only visited [“[182-lady glenmire] [county ”]2645-county ” families]2644-“ county ” families . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty remained puzzled and perplexed long after [I]1165-i had found out the object of [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s visit . When [she]78-mrs jamieson did understand the drift of [the honourable lady]2646-the honourable lady ’s call , it was pretty to see with what quiet dignity [she]78-mrs jamieson received the intimation thus uncourteously given . [She]78-mrs jamieson was not in the least hurt — [she]78-mrs jamieson was of too gentle a spirit for that ; nor was [she]78-mrs jamieson exactly conscious of disapproving of [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s conduct ; but there was something of this feeling in [her]78-mrs jamieson mind , [I]1165-i am sure , which made [her]78-mrs jamieson pass from the subject to [others]838-others in a less flurried and more composed manner than usual . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson was , indeed , the more flurried of [the two]2648-the two , and [I]1165-i could see [she]78-mrs jamieson was glad to take [her]78-mrs jamieson leave . A little while afterwards [Miss Pole]89-miss pole returned , red and indignant . “[1165-i] Well ! to be sure ! [You]1165-i ’ve had [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson [here]2357-here , [I]0-i find from [Martha]98-miss matty ; and [we]1167-we are not to call on [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire . Yes ! [I]0-i met [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson , half - way between here and [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester ’s , and [she]78-mrs jamieson told [me]0-i ; [she]78-mrs jamieson took [me]0-i so by surprise , [I]0-i had nothing to say . [That lady , usually so kind and good - humoured]2649-that lady , usually so kind and good - humoured , was now in a full flow of anger . “[190-viscount arley] And [I]0-i went and ordered a cap this morning , to be quite ready , ” said [she]0-i at last , letting out the secret which gave sting to [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s intimation . “[0-i] [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson shall see if it is so easy to get [me]0-i to make fourth at [a pool]1181-a pool when [she]78-mrs jamieson has none of [her]78-mrs jamieson fine Scotch relations with [her]78-mrs jamieson ! ” In coming out of [church]309-church , the first Sunday on which [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire appeared in [Cranford]1-cranford , [we]2651-we sedulously talked together , and turned [our]2651-we backs on [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson and [[her]78-mrs jamieson guest]2652-her guest . [We]2651-we had the comfort of questioning [Martha]98-miss matty in the afternoon . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty was evidently uneasy at [our]2655-we sarcastic manner of speaking . Perhaps by this time [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire had found out that [[Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s]2657-mrs jamieson ’s was not [the gayest , liveliest house in [the world]333-the world]2658-the gayest , liveliest house in the world ; perhaps [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson had found out that [most of [the county families]2661-the county families]2660-most of the county families were in [London]4-london , and that [those who remained in [the country]710-the country]2662-those who remained in the country were not so alive as [they]2662-those who remained in the country might have been to the circumstance of [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire being in [[their]2662-those who remained in the country neighbourhood]2664-their neighbourhood . Great events spring out of small causes ; so [I]192-mrs deacon will not pretend to say what induced [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson to alter [her]78-mrs jamieson determination of excluding [the Cranford ladies]305-the cranford ladies , and send notes of invitation all round for a small party on the following Tuesday . [Mr Mulliner]193-mr mulliner [himself]193-mr mulliner brought [them]2666-them round . [He]193-mr mulliner _ would _ always ignore the fact of there being a back door to [any house]2667-any house , and gave a louder rat - tat than [[his]193-mr mulliner mistress]2616-his mistress , [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson . [He]193-mr mulliner had three little notes , which [he]193-mr mulliner carried in a large basket , in order to impress [[his]193-mr mulliner mistress]2616-his mistress with an idea of [their]2666-them great weight , though they might easily have gone into [his]193-mr mulliner waistcoat pocket . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty and [I]192-mrs deacon quietly decided that [we]2670-we would have a previous engagement at [home]306-home : it was the evening on which [Miss Matty]98-miss matty usually made candle - lighters of all the notes and letters of the week ; for on Mondays [her]98-miss matty accounts were always made straight — not a penny owing from the week before ; so , by a natural arrangement , making candle - lighters fell upon a Tuesday evening , and gave [us]2670-we a legitimate excuse for declining [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s invitation . But before [our]2670-we answer was written , in came [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , with an open note in [her]0-i hand . “[192-mrs deacon] So ! ” [she]0-i said . “[192-mrs deacon] Ah ! [I]0-i see [you]1198-you have got [your]1198-you note , too . Better late than never . [I]0-i could have told [[my]0-i Lady [Glenmire]182-lady glenmire]1199-my lady glenmire [she]182-lady glenmire would be glad enough of [our]1200-our society before a fortnight was over . ” “[182-lady glenmire] Yes , ” said [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , “[182-lady glenmire] [we]1200-our ’re asked for Tuesday evening . It is [my]0-i usual regular time for looking over the last week ’s bills , and notes , and letters , and making candle - lighters of them ; but that does not seem quite reason enough for saying [I]0-i have a previous engagement at [home]306-home , though [I]0-i meant to make it do . Now , if [you]1198-you would come , [my]0-i conscience would be quite at ease , and luckily the note is not written yet . ” [I]1198-you saw [Miss Pole]89-miss pole ’s countenance change while [Miss Matty]98-miss matty was speaking . “[1198-you] Do n’t [you]1198-you mean to go then ? ” asked [she]98-miss matty . “[1198-you] Oh , no ! ” said , [Miss Matty]98-miss matty quietly . “[1198-you] [You]1198-you do n’t either , [I]0-i suppose ? ” “[1198-you] [I]0-i do n’t know , ” replied [Miss Pole]89-miss pole . “[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i think [I]0-i do , ” said [she]98-miss matty , rather briskly ; and on seeing [Miss Matty]98-miss matty look surprised , [she]0-i added , “[0-i] [You]1198-you see , [one]2460-one would not like [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson to think that anything [she]78-mrs jamieson could do , or say , was of consequence enough to give offence ; it would be a kind of letting down of [ourselves]1203-we , that [I]0-i , for one , should not like . It would be too flattering to [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson if [we]1203-we allowed [her]78-mrs jamieson to suppose that what [she]78-mrs jamieson had said affected [us]1203-we a week , nay ten days afterwards . ” “[78-mrs jamieson] Well ! [I]0-i suppose it is wrong to be hurt and annoyed so long about anything ; and , perhaps , after all , [she]78-mrs jamieson did not mean to vex [us]1203-we . But [I]0-i must say , [I]0-i could not have brought [myself]0-i to say the things [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson did about [our]1203-we not calling . [I]0-i really do n’t think [I]0-i shall go . ” “[0-i] Oh , come ! [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , [you]98-miss matty must go ; [you]98-miss matty know [[our]1203-we friend]493-our friend [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson is much more phlegmatic than [most people]1205-most people , and does not enter into the little delicacies of feeling which [you]98-miss matty possess in so remarkable a degree . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i thought [you]98-miss matty possessed them , too , that day [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson called to tell [us]1203-we not to go , ” said [Miss Matty]98-miss matty innocently . But [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , in addition to [her]89-miss pole delicacies of feeling , possessed a very smart cap , which [she]89-miss pole was anxious to show to an admiring world ; and so [she]89-miss pole seemed to forget all [her]89-miss pole angry words uttered not a fortnight before , and to be ready to act on what [she]89-miss pole called the great Christian principle of “[78-mrs jamieson] Forgive and forget ” ; and [she]89-miss pole lectured [dear Miss Matty]98-miss matty so long on this head that [she]89-miss pole absolutely ended by assuring [her]89-miss pole it was [her]89-miss pole duty , as [[a deceased rector]2672-a deceased rector ’s daughter]2673-a deceased rector ’s daughter , to buy a new cap and go to the party at [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s . So “[78-mrs jamieson] [we]1203-we were most happy to accept , ” instead of “[78-mrs jamieson] regretting that [we]1203-we were obliged to decline . ” [ Picture : [Mr Mulliner]193-mr mulliner ] The expenditure on dress in [Cranford]1-cranford was principally in that one article referred to . If the heads were buried in smart new caps , [the ladies]417-the ladies were like ostriches , and cared not what became of [their]417-the ladies bodies . Old gowns , white and venerable collars , any number of brooches , up and down and everywhere ( some with dogs ’ eyes painted in them ; some that were like small picture - frames with mausoleums and weeping - willows neatly executed in hair inside ; some , again , with miniatures of [ladies]2218-ladies and [gentlemen]619-gentlemen sweetly smiling out of a nest of stiff muslin ) , old brooches for a permanent ornament , and new caps to suit the fashion of the day — [the ladies of [Cranford]1-cranford]300-the ladies of cranford always dressed with chaste elegance and propriety , as [Miss Barker]81-miss barker once prettily expressed it . And with three new caps , and a greater array of brooches than had ever been seen together at one time since [Cranford]1-cranford was [a town]2678-a town , did [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester , and [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , and [Miss Pole]89-miss pole appear on that memorable Tuesday evening . [I]78-mrs jamieson counted seven brooches [myself]78-mrs jamieson on [Miss Pole]89-miss pole ’s dress . Two were fixed negligently in [her]89-miss pole cap ( one was a butterfly made of Scotch pebbles , which a vivid imagination might believe to be the real insect ) ; one fastened [her]89-miss pole net neckerchief ; one [her]89-miss pole collar ; one ornamented the front of [her]89-miss pole gown , midway between [her]89-miss pole throat and waist ; and another adorned the point of [her]89-miss pole stomacher . Where the seventh was [I]78-mrs jamieson have forgotten , but it was somewhere about [her]89-miss pole , [I]78-mrs jamieson am sure . But [I]78-mrs jamieson am getting on too fast , in describing the dresses of [the company]2074-the company . [I]78-mrs jamieson should first relate the gathering on the way to [[Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s]2657-mrs jamieson ’s . [That lady]603-that lady lived in [a large house just outside [the town]281-the town]2682-a large house just outside the town . [A road]2684-a road which had known what it was to be [a street]2685-a street ran right before [the house]2059-the house , which opened out upon [it]2059-the house without any intervening [garden]2426-garden or court . Whatever the sun was about , [he]2688-his never shone on the front of [that house]2689-that house . To be sure , [the living - rooms]2690-the living - rooms were at the back , looking on to [a pleasant garden]2691-a pleasant garden ; the front windows only belonged to [[kitchens]2692-kitchens and [housekeepers]2694-housekeepers ’ rooms]2693-kitchens and housekeepers ’ rooms , and pantries , and in one of them [Mr Mulliner]193-mr mulliner was reported to sit . Indeed , looking askance , [we]2695-we often saw the back of a head covered with hair powder , which also extended itself over [his]2688-his coat - collar down to [his]2688-his very waist ; and this imposing back was always engaged in reading the _ St James ’s Chronicle _ , opened wide , which , in some degree , accounted for the length of time the said newspaper was in reaching [us]2695-we — equal subscribers with [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson , though , in right of [her]78-mrs jamieson honourableness , [she]78-mrs jamieson always had the reading of it first . This very Tuesday , the delay in forwarding the last number had been particularly aggravating ; just when both [Miss Pole]89-miss pole and [Miss Matty]98-miss matty , [the former more especially]2696-the former more especially , had been wanting to see it , in order to coach up the Court news ready for the evening ’s interview with [aristocracy]2697-aristocracy . [Miss Pole]89-miss pole told [us]2695-we [she]89-miss pole had absolutely taken time by the forelock , and been dressed by five o’clock , in order to be ready if the _ St James ’s Chronicle _ should come in at the last moment — the very [_]2698-_ [St James]194-st james ’s Chronicle _ which the powdered head was tranquilly and composedly reading as [we]2695-we passed the accustomed window this evening . “[78-mrs jamieson] The impudence of [the man]424-the man ! ” said [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , in a low indignant whisper . “[424-the man] [I]0-i should like to ask [him]424-the man whether [[his]424-the man mistress]2616-his mistress pays [her]2616-his mistress quarter - share for [his]424-the man exclusive use . ” [We]2695-we looked at [her]89-miss pole in admiration of the courage of [her]89-miss pole thought ; for [Mr Mulliner]193-mr mulliner was an object of great awe to all of [us]2695-we . [He]193-mr mulliner seemed never to have forgotten [his]193-mr mulliner condescension in coming to live at [Cranford]1-cranford . [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty , at times , had stood forth as [the undaunted champion of [her]98-miss matty sex]2699-the undaunted champion of her sex , and spoken to [him]193-mr mulliner on terms of equality ; but even [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty could get no higher . In [his]193-mr mulliner pleasantest and most gracious moods [he]193-mr mulliner looked like [a sulky cockatoo]2700-a sulky cockatoo . [He]193-mr mulliner did not speak except in gruff monosyllables . [He]193-mr mulliner would wait in [the hall]2343-the hall when [we]2695-we begged [him]193-mr mulliner not to wait , and then look deeply offended because [we]2695-we had kept [him]193-mr mulliner there , while , with trembling , hasty hands [we]2695-we prepared [ourselves]2695-we for appearing in company . [Miss Pole]89-miss pole ventured on a small joke as [we]2695-we went [upstairs]340-upstairs , intended , though addressed to [us]2695-we , to afford [Mr Mulliner]193-mr mulliner some slight amusement . [We]2695-we all smiled , in order to seem as if [we]2695-we felt at [our]2695-we ease , and timidly looked for [Mr Mulliner]193-mr mulliner ’s sympathy . Not a muscle of that wooden face had relaxed ; and [we]2695-we were grave in an instant . [[Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s drawing - room]2703-mrs jamieson ’s drawing - room was cheerful ; the evening sun came streaming into [it]2703-mrs jamieson ’s drawing - room , and the large square window was clustered round with flowers . The furniture was white and gold ; not the later style , [Louis Quatorze]195-louis quatorze , [I]2616-his mistress think [they]2704-they call it , all shells and twirls ; no , [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s chairs and tables had not a curve or bend about them . The chair and table legs diminished as [they]2704-they neared the ground , and were straight and square in all their corners . The chairs were all a - row against the walls , with the exception of four or five which stood in a circle round the fire . They were railed with white bars across the back and knobbed with gold ; neither the railings nor the knobs invited to ease . There was a japanned table devoted to literature , on which lay a Bible , a Peerage , and a Prayer - Book . There was another square Pembroke table dedicated to the Fine Arts , on which were a kaleidoscope , conversation - cards , puzzle - cards ( tied together to an interminable length with faded pink satin ribbon ) , and a box painted in fond imitation of the drawings which decorate tea - chests . [Carlo]166-carlo lay on the worsted - worked rug , and ungraciously barked at [us]2695-we as [we]2695-we entered . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson stood up , giving [us]2695-we each a torpid smile of welcome , and looking helplessly beyond [us]2695-we at [Mr Mulliner]193-mr mulliner , as if [she]78-mrs jamieson hoped [he]193-mr mulliner would place [us]2695-we in chairs , for , if [he]193-mr mulliner did not , [she]78-mrs jamieson never could . [I]2616-his mistress suppose [he]193-mr mulliner thought [we]2695-we could find [our]2695-we way to the circle round the fire , which reminded [me]2616-his mistress of [Stonehenge]196-stonehenge , [I]2616-his mistress do n’t know why . [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire came to the rescue of [[our]2695-we hostess]334-our hostess , and , somehow or other , [we]2695-we found [ourselves]2695-we for the first time placed agreeably , and not formally , in [[Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson ’s house]2706-mrs jamieson ’s house . [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire , now [we]2695-we had time to look at [her]182-lady glenmire , proved to be [a bright little woman of middle age , who had been very pretty in the days of [her]182-lady glenmire youth , and who was even yet very pleasant - looking]2707-a bright little woman of middle age , who had been very pretty in the days of her youth , and who was even yet very pleasant - looking . [I]2616-his mistress saw [Miss Pole]89-miss pole appraising [her]89-miss pole dress in the first five minutes , and [I]2616-his mistress take [her]89-miss pole word when [she]89-miss pole said the next day — “[2616-his mistress] [[My]0-i dear]2063-my dear ! ten pounds would have purchased every stitch [she]0-i had on — lace and all . ” It was pleasant to suspect that [a peeress]2708-a peeress could be poor , and partly reconciled [us]2695-we to the fact that [[her]0-i husband]601-her husband had never sat in [the House of Lords]1174-the house of lords ; which , when [we]2695-we first heard of it , seemed a kind of swindling [us]2695-we out of [our]2695-we prospects on false pretences ; a sort of “[822-a lord] [A Lord]822-a lord and [No Lord]1210-no lord ” business . [We]2695-we were all very silent at first . [We]2695-we were thinking what [we]2695-we could talk about , that should be high enough to interest [[My]1210-no lord Lady]1151-my lady . [SIGNOR BRUNONI]96-signor brunoni SOON after the events of which [I]1151-my lady gave an account in [my]1151-my lady last paper , [I]1151-my lady was summoned [home]306-home by [[my]1151-my lady father]2082-my father ’s illness ; and for a time [I]1151-my lady forgot , in anxiety about [him]2082-my father , to wonder how [[my]1151-my lady dear friends at [Cranford]1-cranford]2741-my dear friends at cranford were getting on , or how [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire could reconcile [herself]182-lady glenmire to the dulness of the long visit which [she]182-lady glenmire was still paying to [[her]182-lady glenmire sister - in - law]2641-her sister - in - law , [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson . [She]98-miss matty began many sentences without ending them , running them one into another , in much the same confused sort of way in which written words run together on blotting - paper . [He]321-a gentleman spoke such pretty broken English , [I]0-i could not help thinking of [Thaddeus of]206-thaddeus of [Warsaw]44-warsaw , and [the Hungarian Brothers]207-the hungarian brothers , and [Santo Sebastiani]208-santo sebastiani ; and while [I]0-i was busy picturing [his]321-a gentleman past life to [myself]0-i , [he]321-a gentleman had bowed [me]0-i out of [the room]370-the room . But wait a minute ! [You]1262-you have not heard half [my]0-i story yet ! [I]0-i was going [downstairs]1135-downstairs , when who should [I]0-i meet but [[Betty]81-miss barker ’s second - cousin]1270-betty ’s second - cousin . So , of course , [I]0-i stopped to speak to [her]1270-betty ’s second - cousin for [Betty]81-miss barker ’s sake ; and [she]1270-betty ’s second - cousin told [me]0-i that [I]0-i had really seen [the conjuror]2758-the conjuror — [the gentleman who spoke broken English was [Signor Brunoni]96-signor brunoni [himself]1272-the gentleman who spoke broken english was signor brunoni himself]1272-the gentleman who spoke broken english was signor brunoni himself . Just at this moment [he]321-a gentleman passed [us]1273-us on the stairs , making such a graceful bow ! in reply to which [I]0-i dropped a curtsey — [all foreigners]1274-all foreigners have such polite manners , [one]2460-one catches something of it . But when [he]321-a gentleman had gone [downstairs]1135-downstairs , [I]0-i bethought [me]0-i that [I]0-i had dropped [my]0-i glove in [the Assembly Room]1261-the assembly room ( it was safe in [my]0-i muff all the time , but [I]0-i never found it till afterwards ) ; so [I]0-i went back , and , just as [I]0-i was creeping up [the passage]1278-the passage left on one side of the great screen that goes nearly across [the room]370-the room , who should [I]0-i see but [the very same gentleman that had met [me]0-i before]1280-the very same gentleman that had met me before , and passed [me]0-i on the stairs , coming now forwards from the inner part of [the room]370-the room , to which there is no entrance — [you]1282-you remember , [Miss Matty]98-miss matty — and just repeating , in [his]321-a gentleman pretty broken English , the inquiry if [I]0-i had any business there — [I]0-i do n’t mean that [he]321-a gentleman put it quite so bluntly , but [he]321-a gentleman seemed very determined that [I]0-i should not pass the screen — so , of course , [I]0-i explained about [my]0-i glove , which , curiously enough , [I]0-i found at that very moment . ” [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , then , had seen [the conjuror]2758-the conjuror — [the real , live conjuror]2771-the real , live conjuror ! and numerous were the questions [we]2772-we all asked [her]89-miss pole . “[0-i] Had [he]321-a gentleman a beard ? ” “[321-a gentleman] Was [he]321-a gentleman young , or old ? ” “[321-a gentleman] Fair , or dark ? ” “[321-a gentleman] Did [he]321-a gentleman look”—(unable to shape [my]321-a gentleman question prudently , [I]321-a gentleman put it in another form)—“How[321-a gentleman] did [he]321-a gentleman look ? ” In short , [Miss Pole]89-miss pole was [the heroine of the evening]2773-the heroine of the evening , owing to [her]89-miss pole morning ’s encounter . If [she]89-miss pole was not the rose ( that is to say [the conjuror]2758-the conjuror ) [she]89-miss pole had been near it . Conjuration , sleight of hand , magic , witchcraft , were the subjects of the evening . [Miss Pole]89-miss pole was slightly sceptical , and inclined to think there might be a scientific solution found for even the proceedings of [the Witch of [Endor]45-endor]2775-the witch of endor . [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester believed everything , from ghosts to death - watches . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty ranged between the two — always convinced by [the last speaker]2776-the last speaker . [I]321-a gentleman think [she]98-miss matty was naturally more inclined to [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester ’s side , but a desire of proving [herself]98-miss matty [a worthy sister to [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty]2777-a worthy sister to miss jenkyns kept [her]98-miss matty equally balanced — [Miss Jenkyns]98-miss matty , who would never allow [a servant]2181-a servant to call the little rolls of tallow that formed themselves round candles “[321-a gentleman] winding - sheets , ” but insisted on [their]1283-roley - poleys being spoken of as “[321-a gentleman] [roley - poleys]1283-roley - poleys ! ” [A sister of hers]2779-a sister of hers to be superstitious ! It would never do . After tea , [I]0-i was despatched [downstairs]1135-downstairs into [the dining - parlour]858-the dining - parlour for that volume of the old Encyclopædia which contained the nouns beginning with C , in order that [Miss Pole]89-miss pole might prime [herself]89-miss pole with scientific explanations for the tricks of the following evening . It spoilt the pool at Preference which [Miss Matty]98-miss matty and [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester had been looking forward to , for [Miss Pole]89-miss pole became so much absorbed in [her]89-miss pole subject , and the plates by which it was illustrated , that [we]2782-we felt it would be cruel to disturb [her]89-miss pole otherwise than by one or two well - timed yawns , which [I]0-i threw in now and then , for [I]0-i was really touched by the meek way in which [the two ladies]2783-the two ladies were bearing [their]2783-the two ladies disappointment . But [Miss Pole]89-miss pole only read the more zealously , imparting to [us]2782-we no more information than this — “[0-i] Ah ! [I]0-i see ; [I]0-i comprehend perfectly . A represents the ball . Put A between B and D — no ! between C and F , and turn the second joint of the third finger of [your]1284-your left hand over the wrist of [your]1284-your right H. Very clear indeed ! [[My]0-i dear]2063-my dear [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester , conjuring and witchcraft is a mere affair of the alphabet . Do let [me]0-i read [you]1284-your this one passage ? ” [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester implored [Miss Pole]89-miss pole to spare [her]89-miss pole , saying , from [a child upwards]2784-a child upwards , [she]89-miss pole never could understand being read aloud to ; and [I]0-i dropped the pack of cards , which [I]0-i had been shuffling very audibly , and by this discreet movement [I]0-i obliged [Miss Pole]89-miss pole to perceive that Preference was to have been the order of the evening , and to propose , rather unwillingly , that the pool should commence . The pleasant brightness that stole over [the other two ladies]2785-the other two ladies ’ faces on this ! [Miss Matty]98-miss matty had one or two twinges of self - reproach for having interrupted [Miss Pole]89-miss pole in [her]98-miss matty studies : and did not remember [her]98-miss matty cards well , or give [her]98-miss matty full attention to the game , until [she]98-miss matty had soothed [her]98-miss matty conscience by offering to lend the volume of the Encyclopædia to [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , who accepted it thankfully , and said [Betty]81-miss barker should take it [home]306-home when [she]81-miss barker came with the lantern . The next evening [we]2787-we were all in a little gentle flutter at the idea of the gaiety before [us]2787-we . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty went up to dress betimes , and hurried [me]0-i until [I]0-i was ready , when [we]2787-we found [we]2787-we had an hour - and - a - half to wait before the “[0-i] doors opened at seven precisely . ” And [we]2787-we had only twenty yards to go ! However , as [Miss Matty]98-miss matty said , it would not do to get too much absorbed in anything , and forget the time ; so [she]98-miss matty thought [we]2787-we had better sit quietly , without lighting the candles , till five minutes to seven . So [Miss Matty]98-miss matty dozed , and [I]0-i knitted . At length [we]2787-we set off ; and at the door under the carriage - way at [the “[0-i] George]2788-the “ george , ” [we]2787-we met [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester and [Miss Pole]89-miss pole : [the latter]554-the latter was discussing the subject of the evening with more vehemence than ever , and throwing X ’s and B ’s at [our]2787-we heads like hailstones . [She]98-miss matty had even copied one or two of the “[0-i] receipts”—as [she]98-miss matty called them — for the different tricks , on backs of letters , ready to explain and to detect [Signor Brunoni]96-signor brunoni ’s arts . [We]2787-we went into [the cloak - room]2790-the cloak - room adjoining [the Assembly Room]1261-the assembly room ; [Miss Matty]98-miss matty gave a sigh or two to [her]98-miss matty departed youth , and the remembrance of the last time [she]98-miss matty had been [there]289-there , as [she]98-miss matty adjusted [her]98-miss matty pretty new cap before the strange , quaint old mirror in [the cloak - room]2790-the cloak - room . [The Assembly Room]1261-the assembly room had been added to [the inn]669-the inn , about a hundred years before , by [the different county families , who met together there once a month during the winter to dance and play at cards]2796-the different county families , who met together there once a month during the winter to dance and play at cards . [Many a county beauty]2797-many a county beauty had first swung through the minuet that [she]98-miss matty afterwards danced before [Queen Charlotte]209-queen charlotte in [this very room]2798-this very room . It was said that one of [the Gunnings]210-the gunnings had graced [the apartment]2799-the apartment with [her]98-miss matty beauty ; it was certain that [a rich and beautiful widow]2800-a rich and beautiful widow , [Lady Williams]211-lady williams , had here been smitten with the noble figure of [a young artist]2801-a young artist , who was staying with [some family]2802-some family in [the neighbourhood]2511-the neighbourhood for professional purposes , and accompanied [[his]2801-a young artist patrons]2804-his patrons to [the Cranford Assembly]2805-the cranford assembly . And [a pretty bargain poor [Lady Williams]211-lady williams]2806-a pretty bargain poor lady williams had of [[her]211-lady williams handsome husband]2807-her handsome husband , if all tales were true . Now , [no beauty]2808-no beauty blushed and dimpled along the sides of [the Cranford Assembly Room]2809-the cranford assembly room ; [no handsome artist]2810-no handsome artist won hearts by [his]2810-no handsome artist bow , _ chapeau bras _ in hand ; [the old room]2811-the old room was dingy ; the salmon - coloured paint had faded into a drab ; great pieces of plaster had chipped off from the fine wreaths and festoons on [its]2811-the old room walls ; but still a mouldy odour of aristocracy lingered about [the place]480-the place , and a dusty recollection of the days that were gone made [Miss Matty]98-miss matty and [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester bridle up as [they]2813-they entered , and walk mincingly up [the room]370-the room , as if there were a number of [genteel observers]2815-genteel observers , instead of [two little boys]2816-two little boys with a stick of toffee between [them]2816-two little boys with which to beguile the time . [We]2817-we stopped short at the second front row ; [I]0-i could hardly understand why , until [I]0-i heard [Miss Pole]89-miss pole ask [a stray waiter]2818-a stray waiter if [any of [the county families]2661-the county families]2819-any of the county families were expected ; and when [he]2818-a stray waiter shook [his]2818-a stray waiter head , and believed not , [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester and [Miss Matty]98-miss matty moved forwards , and [[our]2817-we party]2821-our party represented [a conversational square]2822-a conversational square . [The front row]2823-the front row was soon augmented and enriched by [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire and [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson . [We]2817-we six occupied the two front rows , and [our]2817-we aristocratic seclusion was respected by [the groups of [shopkeepers who strayed in from time to time and huddled together on the back benches]2825-shopkeepers who strayed in from time to time and huddled together on the back benches]2824-the groups of shopkeepers who strayed in from time to time and huddled together on the back benches . At least [I]0-i conjectured so , from the noise [they]2824-the groups of shopkeepers who strayed in from time to time and huddled together on the back benches made , and the sonorous bumps [they]2824-the groups of shopkeepers who strayed in from time to time and huddled together on the back benches gave in sitting down ; but when , in weariness of the obstinate green curtain that would not draw up , but would stare at [me]0-i with two odd eyes , seen through holes , as in the old tapestry story , [I]0-i would fain have looked round at [the merry chattering people behind [me]0-i]2826-the merry chattering people behind me , [Miss Pole]89-miss pole clutched [my]0-i arm , and begged [me]0-i not to turn , for “[0-i] it was not the thing . ” What “[0-i] the thing ” was , [I]0-i never could find out , but it must have been something eminently dull and tiresome . However , [we]2817-we all sat eyes right , square front , gazing at the tantalising curtain , and hardly speaking intelligibly , [we]2817-we were so afraid of being caught in the vulgarity of making any noise in a place of public amusement . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson was the most fortunate , for [she]78-mrs jamieson fell asleep . At length the eyes disappeared — the curtain quivered — one side went up before the other , which stuck fast ; it was dropped again , and , with a fresh effort , and a vigorous pull from some unseen hand , it flew up , revealing to [our]2817-we sight [a magnificent gentleman in the Turkish costume , seated before a little table , gazing at [us]2817-we ( [I]0-i should have said with the same eyes that [I]0-i had last seen through the hole in the curtain ) with calm and condescending dignity]2827-a magnificent gentleman in the turkish costume , seated before a little table , gazing at us ( i should have said with the same eyes that i had last seen through the hole in the curtain ) with calm and condescending dignity , “[0-i] like [a being of another sphere]1286-a being of another sphere , ” as [I]0-i heard a sentimental voice ejaculate behind [me]0-i . “[0-i] That ’s not [Signor Brunoni]96-signor brunoni ! ” said [Miss Pole]89-miss pole decidedly ; and so audibly that [I]96-signor brunoni am sure [he]96-signor brunoni heard , for [he]96-signor brunoni glanced down over [his]96-signor brunoni flowing beard at [[our]2817-we party]2821-our party with an air of mute reproach . “[96-signor brunoni] [Signor Brunoni]96-signor brunoni had no beard — but perhaps [he]96-signor brunoni ’ll come soon . ” So [she]89-miss pole lulled [herself]89-miss pole into patience . Meanwhile , [Miss Matty]98-miss matty had reconnoitred through [her]98-miss matty eye - glass , wiped it , and looked again . Then [she]89-miss pole turned round , and said to [me]1287-me , in a kind , mild , sorrowful tone — “[1287-me] [You]1287-me see , [[my]0-i dear]2063-my dear , turbans _ are _ worn . ” But [we]2817-we had no time for more conversation . [The Grand Turk]212-the grand turk , as [Miss Pole]89-miss pole chose to call [him]212-the grand turk , arose and announced [himself]212-the grand turk as [Signor Brunoni]96-signor brunoni . “[1287-me] [I]0-i do n’t believe [him]96-signor brunoni ! ” exclaimed [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , in a defiant manner . [He]212-the grand turk looked at [her]89-miss pole again , with the same dignified upbraiding in [his]212-the grand turk countenance . “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t ! ” [she]89-miss pole repeated more positively than ever . “[96-signor brunoni] [Signor Brunoni]96-signor brunoni had not got that muffy sort of thing about [his]96-signor brunoni chin , but looked like [a close - shaved Christian gentleman]1289-a close - shaved christian gentleman . ” [Miss Pole]89-miss pole ’s energetic speeches had the good effect of wakening up [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson , who opened [her]78-mrs jamieson eyes wide , in sign of the deepest attention — a proceeding which silenced [Miss Pole]89-miss pole and encouraged [the Grand Turk]2829-the grand turk to proceed , which [he]2829-the grand turk did in very broken English — so broken that there was no cohesion between the parts of [his]2829-the grand turk sentences ; a fact which [he]2829-the grand turk [himself]2829-the grand turk perceived at last , and so left off speaking and proceeded to action . Now [we]2830-we _ were _ astonished . How [he]2829-the grand turk did [his]2829-the grand turk tricks [I]1289-a close - shaved christian gentleman could not imagine ; no , not even when [Miss Pole]89-miss pole pulled out [her]89-miss pole pieces of paper and began reading aloud — or at least in a very audible whisper — the separate “[1289-a close - shaved christian gentleman] receipts ” for the most common of [his]2829-the grand turk tricks . If ever [I]1290-i saw [a man]2058-a man frown and look enraged , [I]1290-i saw [the Grand Turk]212-the grand turk frown at [Miss Pole]89-miss pole ; but , as [she]89-miss pole said , what could be expected but unchristian looks from [a Mussulman]213-a mussulman ? If [Miss Pole]89-miss pole were sceptical , and more engrossed with [her]89-miss pole receipts and diagrams than with [his]2829-the grand turk tricks , [Miss Matty]98-miss matty and [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester were mystified and perplexed to the highest degree . [Mrs Jamieson]78-mrs jamieson kept taking [her]78-mrs jamieson spectacles off and wiping them , as if [she]78-mrs jamieson thought it was something defective in them which made [the legerdemain]2832-the legerdemain ; and [Lady Glenmire]182-lady glenmire , who had seen many curious sights in [Edinburgh]9-edinburgh , was very much struck with the tricks , and would not at all agree with [Miss Pole]89-miss pole , who declared that [anybody]2833-anybody could do them with a little practice , and that [she]89-miss pole would , [herself]89-miss pole , undertake to do all [he]2829-the grand turk did , with two hours given to study the Encyclopædia and make [her]89-miss pole third finger flexible . At last [Miss Matty]98-miss matty and [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester became perfectly awestricken . [They]1291-they whispered together . [I]1290-i sat just behind [them]1291-they , so [I]1290-i could not help hearing what [they]1291-they were saying . [Miss Matty]98-miss matty asked [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester “[1290-i] if [she]1290-i thought it was quite right to have come to see such things ? [She]1290-i could not help fearing [they]1291-they were lending encouragement to something that was not quite ” — A little shake of the head filled up the blank . [Mrs Forrester]77-mrs forrester replied , that the same thought had crossed [her]77-mrs forrester mind ; [she]77-mrs forrester too was feeling very uncomfortable , it was so very strange . [She]77-mrs forrester was quite certain that it was [her]77-mrs forrester pocket - handkerchief which was in that loaf just now ; and it had been in [her]77-mrs forrester own hand not five minutes before . [She]77-mrs forrester wondered who had furnished the bread ? [She]77-mrs forrester was sure it could not be [Dakin]214-dakin , because [he]214-dakin was [the churchwarden]2834-the churchwarden . Suddenly [Miss Matty]98-miss matty half - turned towards [me]1291-they — “[1291-they] Will [you]1292-you look , [[my]0-i dear]2063-my dear — [you]1292-you are [a stranger in [the town]281-the town]1294-a stranger in the town , and it wo n’t give rise to unpleasant reports — will [you]1292-you just look round and see if [the rector]2120-the rector is [here]2357-here ? If [he]2120-the rector is , [I]0-i think [we]1298-we may conclude that [this wonderful man]1299-this wonderful man is sanctioned by [the Church]1192-the church , and that will be a great relief to [my]0-i mind . ” [I]2120-the rector looked , and [I]2120-the rector saw [the tall , thin , dry , dusty rector]2835-the tall , thin , dry , dusty rector , sitting surrounded by [National School boys]2836-national school boys , guarded by [troops of [his]2835-the tall , thin , dry , dusty rector own sex]2837-troops of his own sex from any approach of [the many Cranford spinsters]2838-the many cranford spinsters . [His]2835-the tall , thin , dry , dusty rector kind face was all agape with broad smiles , and [the boys]2839-the boys around [him]2835-the tall , thin , dry , dusty rector were in chinks of laughing . [I]2120-the rector told [Miss Matty]98-miss matty that [the Church]1192-the church was smiling approval , which set [her]98-miss matty mind at ease . [ Picture : Afraid of matrimonial reports ] [I]2120-the rector have never named [Mr Hayter]215-mr hayter , [the rector]2120-the rector , because [I]2120-the rector , as [a well - to - do and happy young woman]2842-a well - to - do and happy young woman , never came in contact with [him]215-mr hayter . [He]215-mr hayter was [an old bachelor]733-an old bachelor , but as afraid of matrimonial reports getting abroad about [him]215-mr hayter as [any girl of eighteen]2844-any girl of eighteen : and [he]215-mr hayter would rush into [a shop]2158-a shop or dive down an entry , sooner than encounter [any of [the Cranford ladies in [the street]467-the street]2847-the cranford ladies in the street]2846-any of the cranford ladies in the street ; and , as for the Preference parties , [I]2120-the rector did not wonder at [his]215-mr hayter not accepting invitations to [them]2849-them . To tell the truth , [I]2120-the rector always suspected [Miss Pole]89-miss pole of having given very vigorous chase to [Mr Hayter]215-mr hayter when [he]215-mr hayter first came to [Cranford]1-cranford ; and not the less , because now [she]89-miss pole appeared to share so vividly in [his]215-mr hayter dread lest [her]89-miss pole name should ever be coupled with [his]215-mr hayter . [He]215-mr hayter found all [his]215-mr hayter interests among [the poor and helpless]2850-the poor and helpless ; [he]215-mr hayter had treated [the National School boys]2851-the national school boys this very night to the performance ; and virtue was for once its own reward , for [they]2851-the national school boys guarded [him]215-mr hayter right and left , and clung round [him]215-mr hayter as if [he]215-mr hayter had been [the queen - bee]2852-the queen - bee and [they]2851-the national school boys [the swarm]2853-the swarm . [He]215-mr hayter felt so safe in [their]2851-the national school boys environment that [he]215-mr hayter could even afford to give [[our]2854-we party]2821-our party a bow as [we]2854-we filed out .
